[15:263] So then you have been deprived of nothing, yea, you have been a gainer: you have received no wrongs, rather you have been crowned; in that you are become better disciplined in soul; are made like to God; are set free from the care of money; are made possessor of the kingdom of heaven.

[15:264] All these things therefore taking into account, let us restrain ourselves in injuries, beloved, in order that we may both be freed from the tumult of this present life, and cast out all unprofitable sadness of spirit, and may obtain the joy to come; through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father and the Holy Spirit be glory, power, honor, now, henceforth, and for ever and ever, Amen.

[16:1] Homily XVII.

[16:2] Cor.

[16:3] vi.

[16:4] "All things are lawful for me, but not all things are expedient.

[16:5] All things are lawful for me, but I will not be brought into the power of any.

[16:6] Here he glances at the gluttons.

[16:7] For since he intends to assail the fornicator again, and fornication arises from luxuriousness and want of moderation, he strongly chastises this passion.

[16:8] It cannot be that he speaks thus with regard to things forbidden, such not being "lawful:" but of things which seem to be indifferent.

[16:9] To illustrate my meaning: "It is lawful," he says, "to eat and to drink; but it is not expedient with excess".

[16:10] And so that marvellous and unexpected turn of his, which he is often wont to adopt; (Cf.

[16:11] Rom.

[16:12] xii.

[16:13] ;  Cor.

[16:14] vii.

[16:15] ) bringing his argument clear round to its contrary, this he manages to introduce here also; and he signifies that to do what is in one's power not only is not expedient, but even is not a part of power, but of slavery.

[16:16] And first, he dissuades them on the ground of the inexpediency of the thing, saying, "they are not expedient:" in the next place, on that of its contrariety to itself, saying, "I will not be brought under the power of any".

[16:17] This is his meaning: "You are at liberty to eat," says he; "well then, remain in liberty, and take heed that you do not become a slave to this appetite: for he who uses it properly, he is master of it; but he that exceeds the proper measure is no longer its master but its slave, since gluttony reigns paramount within him".

[16:18] Do you perceive how, where the man thought he had authority Paul points out that he is under authority? For this is his custom, as I was saying before, to give all objections a turn the contrary way.

[16:19] It is just this which he has done here.

[16:20] For mark; each of them was saying, "I have power to live luxuriously".

[16:21] He replies, "In doing so, thou art not so much acting as one who had power over a thing, but rather as being thyself subject to some such power.

[16:22] For thou hast not power even over thine own belly, so long as thou art dissolute, but it hath power over thee".

[16:23] And the same we may say both of riches and of other things.

[16:24] Ver.

[16:25] "Meats for the belly".

[16:26] By "the belly" here he means not the stomach, but the stomach's voraciousness.

[16:27] As when he says, (Philip.

[16:28] iii.

[16:29] ) "Whose God is their belly:" not speaking about that part of the body, but about greediness.

[16:30] To prove that so it is, hear what follows: "And the belly for meats; but the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord".

[16:31] And yet "the belly" also is of "the body".

[16:32] But he puts down two pairs of things, "meats" and gluttony, (which he terms "the belly;") "Christ," and "the body".

[16:33] What then is the meaning of, "Meats for the belly?" "Meats," he says, are on good terms with gluttony, and it with them.

[16:34] It cannot therefore lead us unto Christ, but drags towards these.

[16:35] For it is a strong and brutal passion, and makes us slaves, and puts us upon ministering to the belly.

[16:36] Why then art thou excited and gaping after food, O man? For the end of that service is this, and nothing further shall be seen of it: but as one was waiting on some mistress, it abides keeping up this slavery, and advances no further, and has no other employment but this same fruitless one.

[16:37] And the two are connected together and destroyed together; "the belly" with "the meats," and "the meats" with "the belly;" winding out a sort of interminable course; just as from a corrupt body worms may be produced, and again by worms the body consumed; or as it were a wave swoln high and breaking, and having no further effect.

[16:38] But these things he says not concerning food and the body, but it is the passion of greediness and excess in eatables which he is censuring: and what follows shews it.

[16:39] For he proceeds:  "But God shall bring to nought both it and them:" speaking not of the stomach, but of immoderate desire: not of food but of high feeding.

[16:40] For with the former he is not angry, but even lays down rules about them, saying, ( Tim.

[16:41] vi.

[16:42] ) "Having food and covering we shall be therewith content".

[16:43] However, thus he stigmatizes the whole thing; its amendment (after advice given) being left by him to prayer.

[16:44] But some say that the words are a prophecy, declaring the state which shall be in the life to come, and that there is no eating or drinking there.

[16:45] Now if that which is moderate shall have an end, much more ought we to abstain from excess.

[16:46] Then lest any one should suppose that the body is the object of his censure, and suspect that from a part he is blaming the whole, and say that the nature of the body was the cause of gluttony or of fornication, hear what follows.

[16:47] "I blame not," he says, "the nature of the body, but the immoderate license of the mind".

[16:48] And therefore he subjoins, "Now the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord;" for it was not formed for this purpose, to live riotously and commit fornication, as neither was the belly to be greedy; but that it might follow Christ as a Head, and that the Lord might be set over the body.

[16:49] Let us be overcome with shame, let us be horror-struck, that after we have been counted worthy of such great honor as to become members of Him that sitteth on high, we defile ourselves with so great evils.

[16:50] Having now sufficiently condemned the glutton, he uses also the hope of things to come to divert us from this wickedness: saying,  Ver.

[16:51] And God both raised up the Lord, and will raise up us also through His power.

[16:52] Do you perceive again his Apostolical wisdom? For he is always establishing the credibility of the Resurrection from Christ, and especially now.

[16:53] For if our body be a member of Christ, and Christ be risen, the body also shall surely follow the Head.

[16:54] "Through his power".

[16:55] For since he had asserted a thing disbelieved and not to be apprehended by reasonings, he hath left entirely to His incomprehensible power the circumstances of Christ's own Resurrection, producing this too as no small demonstration against them.

[16:56] And concerning the Resurrection of Christ he did not insert this: for he did not say, "And God shall also raise up the Lord;"—for the thing was past and gone;—but how? "And God both raised up the Lord;" nor was there need of any proof.

[16:57] But concerning our resurrection, since it has not yet come to pass, he spoke not thus, but how? "And will raise up us also through His power:" by the reliance to be placed on the power of the Worker, he stops the mouths of the gainsayers.

[16:58] Further: if he ascribe unto the Father the Resurrection of Christ, let not this at all disturb thee.

[16:59] For not as though Christ were powerless, hath he put this down, for He it is Himself who saith, (S.

[16:60] John ii.

[16:61] ) "Destroy this Temple, and in three days I will raise it up:" and again, (S.

[16:62] John x.

[16:63] ) "I have power to lay down My life, and I have power to take it again".

[16:64] And Luke also in the Acts says, (c.

[16:65] i.

[16:66] ) "To whom also He shewed Himself alive".

[16:67] Wherefore then does Paul so speak? Because both the acts of the Son are imputed unto the Father, and the Father's unto the Son.

[16:68] For He saith, (S.

[16:69] John v.

[16:70] ) "Whatsoever things He doeth, these the Son also doeth in like manner".

[16:71] And very opportunely he here made mention of the Resurrection, keeping down by those hopes the tyranny of gluttonous desire; and all but saying, Thou hast eaten, hast drunk to excess: and what is the result? Nothing, save only destruction.

[16:72] Thou hast been conjoined unto Christ; and what is the result? A great and marvellous thing: the future Resurrection, that glorious one, and transcending all utterance!   Let no one therefore go on disbelieving the Resurrection: but if a man disbelieve, let him think how many things He made from nothing, and admit it as a proof also of the other.

[16:73] For the things which are already past are stranger by far, and fraught with overpowering wonder.

[16:74] Just consider.

[16:75] He took earth and mixed it, and made man; earth which existed not before this.

[16:76] How then did the earth become man? And how was it produced from nothing? And, how, all the things that were made from it? the endless sorts of irrational creatures; of seeds; of plants; no pangs of travail having preceded in the one case, no rains having come down upon the others; no tillage seen, no oxen, no plough, nor any thing else contributing to their production? Why, for this cause the lifeless and senseless thing was made to put forth in the beginning so many kinds of plants and irrational creatures, in order that from the very first He might instruct thee in the doctrine of Resurrection.

[16:77] For this is more inexplicable than the Resurrection.

[16:78] For it is not the same thing to rekindle an extinguished lamp, and to shew fire that has never yet appeared.

[16:79] It is not the same thing to raise up again a house which has fallen down, and to produce one which has never at all had an existence.

[16:80] For in the former case, if nothing else, yet the material was given to work with: but in the latter, not even the substance appeared.

[16:81] Wherefore He made first that which seemed to be the more difficult, to the end that hereby thou mightest admit that which is the more easy; more difficult, I say, not to God, but as far as our reasonings can follow the subject.

[16:82] For with God nothing is difficult: but as the painter who has made one likeness will make ten thousand with ease, so also with God it is easy to make worlds without number and end.

[16:83] Rather, as it is easy for you to conceive a city and worlds without bound, so unto God is it easy to make them; or rather again it is easier by far.

[16:84] For thou consumest time, brief though it be, in thy conception; but God not even this, but as much as stones are heavier than any of the lightest things, yea even than our minds; so much is our mind surpassed by the rapidity of God's work of creation.

[16:85] Do you marvel at His power on the earth? Think again how the heaven was made, not yet being; how the innumerable stars, how the sun, how the moon; and all these things not yet being.

[16:86] Again, tell me how after they were made they stood fast, and upon what? What foundation have they? and what the earth? What comes next to the earth? and again, what after that which came next to the earth? Do you see into what an eddy the eye of your mind is plunged, unless you quickly take refuge in faith and the incomprehensible power of the Maker?  But if you choose from human things also to make conjecture, you will be able by degrees to find wings for your understanding.

[16:87] "What kind of human things?" may be asked.

[16:88] Do you not see the potters, how they fashion the vase which had been broken in pieces and become shapeless? Those who fuse the ore from the mine, how the earth in their hands turns out (τὴν γῆν χρύσιον ἀποφαίνουσι) gold, or silver, or copper? Others again who work in glass, how they transform the sand into one compact and transparent substance? Shall I speak of the dressers of leather, the dyers of purple vestments; how they make that which had received their tint shew as one thing, when it had been another? Shall I speak of the generation of our own race? Doth not a small seed, at first without form and impress, enter into the womb which receives it? Whence then the so intricate formation of the living creature? What is the wheat? Is it not cast a naked seed into the earth? After it has been cast there, doth it not decay? Whence is the ear, the beard, the stalk, and all the other parts? Doth not often a little grain of a fig fall into the ground, and produce both root, and branches, and fruit? And dost thou hereupon admit each of these and make no curious enquiries, and of God alone dost thou demand account, in His work of changing the fashion of our body? And how can such things be pardonable?  These things and such like we say to the Greeks.

[16:89] For to those who are obedient to the Scriptures, I have no occasion to speak at all.

[16:90] I say, if you intend to pry curiously into all His doings, what shall God have more than men? And yet even of men there are many about whom we do not so enquire.

[16:91] Much more then ought we to abstain from impertinent inquiry about the wisdom of God, and from demanding accounts of it: in the first place, because He is trustworthy who affirmeth: in the second place, because the matter admits not investigation by reasonings.

[16:92] For God is not so abjectly poor as to work such things only as can be apprehended by the weakness of thy reasonings.

[16:93] And if thou comprehendest not the work of an artisan, much less of God, the best of artificers.

[16:94] Disbelieve not then the Resurrection, for very far will ye be from the hope of that which is to come.

[16:95] But what is the wise argument of the gain-sayers; rather, I should say, their exceeding senseless one? "Why how, when the body is mixed up with the earth and is become earth, and this again is removed elsewhere, how," say they, "shall it rise again?" To thee this seems impossible, but not to the unsleeping Eye.

[16:96] For unto that all things are clear.

[16:97] And thou in that confusion seest no distinction of parts; but He knows them all.

[16:98] Since also the heart of thy neighbor thou knowest not, nor the things in it; but He knoweth all.

[16:99] If then, because of thy not knowing how God raiseth men up, thou believest not that He doth raise them, wilt thou disbelieve that He knoweth also what is in thy mind? for neither is that obvious to view.

[16:100] And yet in the body it is visible matter, though it be dissolved: but those thoughts are invisible.

[16:101] Shall He then who knoweth with all certainty the invisible things, not see the things which be visible, and easily distinguish the scattered parts of the body? I suppose this is plain to every one.

[16:102] Do not then disbelieve the Resurrection; for this is a doctrine of the Devil.

[16:103] This is what the Devil is earnest for, not only that the Resurrection may be disbelieved, but good works also may be done away with.

[16:104] For the man who does not expect that he shall rise again and give an account of the things which he has done, will not quickly apply himself to virtue; will in turn come to disbelieve the Resurrection entirely: for both these are established by each other; vice by unbelief, and unbelief by vice.

[16:105] For the conscience filled with many wickednesses, fearing and trembling for the recompense to come and not willing to provide itself with comfort by changing to what is most excellent, is fain to repose in unbelief.

[16:106] Thus when thou deniest resurrection and judgment, the other for his part will say, "Then shall I also not have to render account of my bold deeds".

[16:107] But why saith Christ? (St.

[16:108] Matt.

[16:109] xxii.

[16:110] ) "Ye do err, not knowing the Scriptures, nor the power of God".

[16:111] For God would not have wrought so many things, had He intended not to raise us up again, but to dissolve and blot us out in annihilation.

[16:112] He would not have spread out this heaven, He would not have stretched the earth beneath, He would not have made all the rest of the universe only for this short life.

[16:113] But if all these are for the present, what will He not do for that which is to come? If, on the contrary, there is to be no future life, we are in this respect of far meaner account than the things which have been made for our sakes.

[16:114] For both the heaven, and the earth, and the sea, and the rivers, are more lasting than we are: and some even of the brutes; since the raven, and the race of elephants, and many other creatures, have a longer enjoyment of the present life.

[16:115] To us, moreover, life is both short and toilsome, but not to them.

[16:116] Theirs is both long, and freer from grief and cares.

[16:117] "What then? tell me: hath he made the slaves better than the masters?" Do not, I beseech thee, do not reason thus, O man, nor be so poverty-stricken in mind, nor be ignorant of the riches of God, having such a Master.

[16:118] For even from the beginning God desired to make thee immortal, but thou wert not willing.

[16:119] Since the things also of that time were dark hints of immortality: the converse with God; the absence of uneasiness from life; the freedom from grief, and cares, and toils, and other things which belong to a temporary existence.

[16:120] For Adam had no need either of a garment or a shelter, or any other provision of this sort; but rather was like to the Angels; and many of the things to come he foreknew, and was filled with great wisdom.

[16:121] Even what God did in secret, he knew, I mean with regard to the woman: wherefore also he said, "This is now bone of my bone, and flesh of my flesh".

[16:122] (Gen.

[16:123] ii.

[16:124] ) Labor came into being afterwards: so did sweat, so did shame, and cowardice, and want of confidence.

[16:125] But on that day there was no grief, nor pain, nor lamentation.

[16:126] But he abode not in that dignity.

[16:127] What then, saith one, am I to do? must I perish on his account? I reply, first, It is not on his account: for neither hast thou remained without sin: though it be not the same sin, at least there is some other which thou hast committed.

[16:128] And again, you have not been injured by his punishment, but rather have been a gainer.

[16:129] For if you had been to remain altogether mortal, perchance what is said would have had some reason in it.

[16:130] But now thou art immortal, and if thou wilt, thou mayest shine brighter than the sun itself.

[16:131] "But," says one, "had I not received a mortal body, I had not sinned".

[16:132] Tell me then, had he a mortal body when he sinned? Surely not: for if it had been mortal before, it would not have undergone death as a punishment afterwards.

[16:133] And that a mortal body is no hindrance to virtue, but that it keeps men in order and is of the greatest service, is plain from what follows.

[16:134] If the expectation of immortality alone so lifted up Adam; had he been even immortal in reality, to what a pitch of arrogance would he not have proceeded? And as things are, after sinning you may do away with your sins, the body being abject, falling away, and subject to dissolution: for these thoughts are sufficient to sober a man.

[16:135] But if you had sinned in an immortal body, your sins were likely to have been more lasting.

[16:136] Mortality then is not the cause of sin: accuse it not: but the wicked will is the root of all the mischief.

[16:137] For why was not Abel at all the worse for his body? Why are the devils not at all the better for being incorporeal? Wilt thou hear why the body's becoming mortal, so far from hurting, has been positively useful? Mark how much thou gainest thereby, if thou art sober.

[16:138] It drags thee back and pulls thee off from wickedness, by griefs and pains and labors and other such things.

[16:139] "But it tempts men to uncleanness," perhaps you will say.

[16:140] Not the body, but incontinence, doth this.

[16:141] For all these things which I was mentioning certainly do belong to the body: on which account it is impossible that a man who has entered into this life should escape disease and pain and lowness of spirits: but that he commit no uncleanness is possible.

[16:142] Thus it appears that if the affections of vice were part of the nature of the body they would be universal: since all things natural are so; but to commit fornication is not so.

[16:143] Pain indeed cometh of nature: but to commit fornication proceeds from deliberate purpose.

[16:144] Blame not the body then; let not the Devil take away thine honor, which God hath given thee.

[16:145] For if we choose, the body is an excellent bridle to curb the wanton sallies of the soul, to pull down haughtiness, to repress arrogance, to minister to us in the greatest achievements of virtue.

[16:146] For tell me not of those who have lost their senses; since we often see horses, after they have thrown out their drivers, dashing with their reins over the precipices, and yet we do not blame the rein.

[16:147] For it is not the breaking of that which caused it all, but the driver not holding them in was the ruin of every thing.

[16:148] Just so do thou reason in this case.

[16:149] If thou seest a young person living in orphanhood and doing innumerable evil things, blame not the body, but the charioteer who is dragged on, I mean, the man's faculty of reasoning.

[16:150] For as the reins give no trouble to the charioteer, but the charioteer is the cruise of all the mischief through his not holding them properly: (and therefore do they often exact a penalty of him, entangling themselves with him, and dragging him on, and compelling him to partake in their own mishap:) so is it also in the case before us.

[16:151] "I," say the reins, "made bloody the horse's mouth as long as you held me: but since you threw me away, I require satisfaction for your contempt, and I entwine myself about you, and drag you along, so as not to incur the same usage again".

[16:152] Let no one then blame the reins, but himself and his own corrupt mind.

[16:153] For over us too is a charioteer, even reason: and the reins are the body, connecting the horses with the charioteer; if then these be in good condition, you will suffer no harm: but if you let them go, you have annihilated and ruined every thing.

[16:154] Let us be temperate then, and lay all blame not on the body, but on the evil mind.

[16:155] For this is the Devil's special work, to make foolish men accuse the body and God and their neighbor, rather than their own perverted minds; lest, having discovered the cause, they get free from the root of the evils.

[16:156] But do ye, being aware of his design, direct your wrath against him: and having set the charioteer upon the car, bend the eye of your minds towards God.

[16:157] For in all other instances he that appoints the games contributes nothing, but only awaits the end.

[16:158] But in this case, He is all in all, who appointed the contest, even God.

[16:159] Him therefore let us render propitious, and surely we shall obtain the blessings in store; through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, to Whom, with the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now, henceforth, and for evermore, Amen.

[17:1] Homily XVIII.

[17:2] Cor.

[17:3] vi.

[17:4] "Know ye not that your bodies are members of Christ? Shall I then take away the members of Christ, and make them members of a harlot? God forbid.

[17:5] Having passed on from the fornicator to the covetous person, he comes back to the former from the latter, no longer henceforth discoursing with him but with the others who had not committed fornication.

[17:6] And in the act of securing them lest they fall into the same sins, he assails him again.

[17:7] For he that has committed sin, though you direct your words to another, is stung even in that way; his conscience being thoroughly awakened and scourging him.

[17:8] Now the fear of punishment indeed was enough to keep them in chastity.

[17:9] But seeing that he does not wish by fear alone to set these matters right, he uses both threatenings and reasons.

[17:10] Now upon that other occasion, having stated the sin, and prescribed the punishment, and pointed out the harm which intercourse with the fornicator brought upon all, he left off, and passed to the subject of covetousness: and having threatened the covetous and all the rest whom he mentioned with expulsion from the kingdom, he so concluded his discourse.

[17:11] But here he takes in hand the work of admonition in a yet more terrific manner.

[17:12] For as he that only punishes a sin and does nothing to point out its most extreme lawlessness, produces no such great effect by his chastisement: so again, he who only abashes and fails to terrify by his mode of punishing, does not very keenly hit men of hardened minds.

[17:13] Wherefore Paul does both: here he abashes, saying, "Know ye not that we shall judge angels?" there again he terrifies, saying, "Know ye not that the covetous shall not inherit the kingdom of God?"  And in regard to the fornicator, he again uses this order of discourse.

[17:14] For having terrified him by what he had said before; first cutting him off and delivering him to Satan, and then reminding him of that day which is coming; he abashes him again by saying, "Know ye not that your bodies are members of Christ?" thenceforth speaking as to children of noble birth.

[17:15] For whereas he had said, "Now the body is for the Lord," he indicates it more plainly now.

[17:16] And in another place as well he does this same thing, saying, (xii.

[17:17] ) "Now ye are the body of Christ, and severally members thereof".

[17:18] And the same figure he often employs, not with the same aim, but at one time to shew His love, and at another to increase their fear.

[17:19] But here he has employed it to startle and fill them with alarm.

[17:20] "Shall I then take the members of Christ, and make them members of a harlot? God forbid".

[17:21] Nothing can be apter to strike horror than this expression.

[17:22] He said not, "Shall I take the members of Christ, and join them on to a harlot?" but what? "make them members of a harlot;" which surely would strike more keenly.

[17:23] Then he makes out how the fornicator becomes this, saying thus, "Know ye not that he that is joined unto a harlot is one body?" How is this evident? "For the twain, saith He, shall become one".

[17:24] Ver.

[17:25] "But he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit".

[17:26] For the conjunction suffers the two no longer to be two, but makes them both one.

[17:27] Now mark again, how he proceeds by means of the bare terms, conducting his accusation in the names of the harlot and of Christ.

[17:28] Ver.

[17:29] "Flee fornication".

[17:30] He said not, "abstain from fornication," but "Flee:" that is, with all zeal make to yourselves deliverance from that evil.

[17:31] "Every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body".

[17:32] This is less than what went before; but since he had to speak of fornicators, he amplifies that guilt by topics drawn from all quarters, from greater things and smaller alike, making the charge heinous.

[17:33] And, in fact, that former topic was addressed to the more religious, but this to the weaker sort.

[17:34] For this also is characteristic of the wisdom of Paul, not only to allege the great things wherewith to abash men, but the lesser also, and the consideration of what is disgraceful and unseemly.

[17:35] "What then," say you, "does not the murderer stain his hand? What, of the covetous person and the extortioner?" I suppose it is plain to every one.

[17:36] But since it was not possible to mention anything worse than the fornicator, he amplifies the crime in another way, by saying that in the fornicator the entire body becomes defiled.

[17:37] For it is as polluted as if it had fallen into a vessel of filth, and been immersed in defilement.

[17:38] And this too is our way.

[17:39] For from covetousness and extortion no one would make haste to go into a bath, but as if nothing had happened returns to his house.

[17:40] Whereas from intercourse with a harlot, as having become altogether unclean, he goes to a bath.

[17:41] To such a degree does the conscience retain from this sin a kind of sense of unusual shame.

[17:42] Both however are bad, both covetousness and fornication; and both cast into hell.

[17:43] But as Paul doeth every thing with good management, so by whatever topics he had he magnified the sin of fornication.

[17:44] Ver.

[17:45] "Know ye not that your body is a temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you?" He did not merely say, "of the Spirit," but, "which is in you;" which was the part of one who also was soothing.

[17:46] And again, explaining himself still further, he added, "which ye have from God".

[17:47] He mentioned Him that gave also, both exalting the hearer and putting him in fear, both by the magnitude of the deposit, and by the munificence of Him that made it.

[17:48] "And ye are not your own".

[17:49] This is not only to abash, but even to force men towards virtue.

[17:50] "For why," says he; "doest thou what thou wilt? thou art not thine own master".

[17:51] But these things he said, not to take away free-will.

[17:52] For so in saying, "All things are lawful for me, but not all things are expedient," he does not take away our liberty.

[17:53] And here again, writing, "Ye are not your own;" he makes no infringement upon freedom of choice, but he leads away from vice and indicates the guardian care of the Lord.

[17:54] And therefore he added, "For ye were bought with a price".

[17:55] "But if I am not my own, upon what ground do you demand of me duties to be done? And why do you go on to say again, "Glorify God therefore in your body and in your spirit, which are God's?" What then is the meaning of, "ye are not your own?" And what does he wish to prove thereby? To settle them in a state of security against sin, and against following the improper desires of the mind.

[17:56] For indeed we have many improper wishes: but we must repress them, for we can.

[17:57] And if we could not, exhortation would be in vain.

[17:58] Mark, accordingly, how he secures his ground.

[17:59] For having said, "Ye are not your own," he adds not, "But are under compulsion;" but, "Ye were bought with a price".

[17:60] Why sayest thou this? Surely on another ground, one might say perhaps, you should have persuaded men, pointing out that we have a Master.

[17:61] But this is common to the Greeks also together with us: whereas the expression, "Ye were bought with a price," belongs to us peculiarly.

[17:62] For he reminds us of the greatness of the benefit and of the mode of our salvation, signifying that when we were alienated, we were "bought:" and not simply "bought," but, "with a price".

[17:63] "Glorify then, take up and bear, God in your body, and in your spirit".

[17:64] Now these things he says, that we may not only flee fornication in the body, but also in the spirit of our mind abstain from every wicked thought, and from driving away grace.

[17:65] "Which are God's".

[17:66] For as he had said "your," he added therefore, "which are God's:" continually reminding us that all things belong to the Lord, both body and soul and spirit: For some say, that the words "in the spirit" mean the gracious Gift; for if That be in us, God is glorified.

[17:67] And this will be, if we have a clean heart.

[17:68] But He has spoken of these things as God's, not only because He brought them into being, but also because, when they were alienated, He won them again a second time, paying as the price, the blood of the Son.

[17:69] Mark how He brought the whole to completion in Christ, how He raised us up into heaven.

[17:70] "Ye are members of Christ," saith he, "ye are a temple of the Spirit".

[17:71] Become not then "members of a harlot:" for it is not your body which is insulted; since it is not your body at all, but Christ's.

[17:72] And these things he spake, both to make manifest His loving-kindness in that our body is His, and to withdraw us from all evil license.

[17:73] For if the body be another's, "you have no authority," says he, "to insult another's body; and especially when it is the Lord's; nor yet to pollute a temple of the Spirit".

[17:74] For if any one who invades a private house and makes his way revelling into it, must answer for it most severely; think what dreadful things he shall endure who makes a temple of the King a robber's lurking place.

[17:75] Considering these things therefore, reverence thou Him that dwelleth within.

[17:76] For the Paraclete is He.

[17:77] Thrill before Him that is enfolded and cleaves unto thee; for Christ is He.

[17:78] Hast thou indeed made thyself members of Christ? Think thus, and continue chaste; whose members they were, and Whose they have become.

[17:79] Erewhile they were members of an harlot, and Christ hath made them members of His own Body.

[17:80] Thou hast therefore henceforth no authority over them.

[17:81] Serve Him that hath set thee free.

[17:82] For supposing you had a daughter, and in extreme madness had let her out to a procurer for hire, and made her live a harlot's life, and then a king's son were to pass by, and free her from that slavery, and join her in marriage to himself; you could have no power thenceforth to bring her into the brothel.

[17:83] For you gave her up once for all, and sold her.

[17:84] Such as this is our case also.

[17:85] We let out our own flesh for hire unto the Devil, that grievous procurer: Christ saw and set it free, and withdrew it from that evil tyranny; it is not then ours any more but His who delivered it.

[17:86] If you be willing to use it as a King's bride, there is none to hinder; but if you bring it where it was before, you will suffer just what they ought who are guilty of such outrages.

[17:87] Wherefore you should rather adorn instead of disgracing it.

[17:88] For you have no authority over the flesh in the wicked lusts, but in those things alone which God may enjoin.

[17:89] Let the thought enter your mind at least from what great outrage God hath delivered it.

[17:90] For in truth never did any harlot expose herself so shamefully as our nature before this.

[17:91] For robberies, murders, and every wicked thought entered in and lay with the soul, and for a small and vulgar hire, the present pleasure.

[17:92] For the soul, being mixed up with all wicked devices and deeds, reaped this reward and no other.

[17:93] However, in the time before this, bad though it were to be such as these, it was not so bad: but after heaven, after the King's courts, after partaking of the tremendous Mysteries, again to be contaminated, what pardon shall this have? Or, dost thou not think that the covetous too, and all those whom he recounted before, have the Devil to lie with them? And dost thou not judge that the women who beautify themselves for pollution have intercourse with him? Why, who shall gainsay this word? But if any be contentious, let him uncover the soul of the women who behave in this unseemly manner, and he will surely see that the wicked demon closely entwined with them.

[17:94] For it is hard, brethren, it is hard, perchance even impossible, when the body is thus beautified, for the soul to be beautified at the same time: but one must needs be neglected, while the other is cared for.

[17:95] For nature does not allow these to take place together.

[17:96] Wherefore he saith, "He that is joined to a harlot is one body; but he that is joined to the Lord is one Spirit".

[17:97] For such an one becomes thenceforth Spirit, although a body envelope him.

[17:98] For when nothing corporeal nor gross nor earthly is around him, the body doth but merely envelope him; since the whole government of him is in the soul and the Spirit.

[17:99] In this way God is glorified.

[17:100] Wherefore both in the Prayer we are commanded to say, "Hallowed be Thy Name:" and Christ saith also, "Let your light shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven".

[17:101] So do the heavens also glorify Him, uttering no voice, but by the view of them attracting wonder and referring the glory unto the Great Artificer.

[17:102] So let us glorify Him also, or rather more than they.

[17:103] For we can if we will.

[17:104] For not so much do the heaven nor day nor night glorify God, as a holy soul.

[17:105] For as one that gazeth upon the beauty of the heaven, saith, "Glory be to Thee, O God! How fair a work hast thou formed!" so too when beholding virtue in any man: nay, and much more so in the latter instance.

[17:106] For from these works of creation all do not glorify God; but many even assert that the things which exist are self-moving: and others impute to demons the workmanship of the world and providence; and these indeed greatly and unpardonably err: but in regard to the virtue of man, no one shall have power to hold these shameless opinions, but shall assuredly glorify God when he seeth him that serveth Him living in goodness.

[17:107] For who shall help being astonished when one being a man, and partaking of our common nature, and living among other men, like adamant yields not at all to the swarm of passions? When being in the midst of fire and iron and wild beasts, he is even harder than adamant and vanquishes all for the Word of godliness' sake? when he is injured, and blesses; when he is evil reported of, and praises; when he is despitefully used, and prays for those who injure him; when he is plotted against, and does good to those that fight with him and lay snares for him? For these things, and such as these, will glorify God far more than the heaven.

[17:108] For the Greeks when they behold the heavens feel no awe; but when they see a holy man exhibiting a severe course of life with all strictness, they shrink away and condemn themselves.

[17:109] Since when he that partakes of the same nature as themselves is so much above them, a great deal more so than the heaven is above the earth, even against their inclination they think that it is a Divine power which works these things.

[17:110] Wherefore He saith, "And glorify your Father which is in heaven".

[17:111] Wilt thou learn also from another place how by the life of His servants God is glorified, and how by miracles? Nebuchadnezzar once threw the Three Children into the furnace.

[17:112] Then when he saw that the fire had not prevailed over them, he saith, (Dan.

[17:113] iii.

[17:114] LXX.

[17:115] ἐκ τῆς καμίνου added.

[17:116] ) "Blessed be God, who hath sent His Angel, and delivered his servants out of the furnace, because they trusted in Him and have changed the word of the king".

[17:117] "How sayest thou? Hast thou been despised, and dost thou admire those who have spit upon you?" "Yes," saith he, "and for this very reason, that I was despised".

[17:118] And of the marvel he gives this reason.

[17:119] So that not because of the miracle alone was glory given to God at that time, but also because of the purpose of those who have been thrown in.

[17:120] Now if any one would examine this point and the other, as they are in themselves, this will appear not less than that: for to persuade souls to brave a furnace is not less in respect of the wonder than to deliver from a furnace.

[17:121] For how can it be otherwise than astonishing for the Emperor of the world, with so many arms around him, and legions, and generals, and viceroys, and consuls, and land and sea subject to his sway, to be despised by captive children; for the bound to overcome the binder and conquer all that army? Neither was there any power in the king and his company to do what they would, no, not even with the furnaces for an ally.

[17:122] But they who were naked, and slaves, and strangers, and few, (for what number could be more contemptible than three?) being in chains, vanquished an innumerable army.

[17:123] For already now was death despised, since Christ was henceforth about to sojourn in the world.

[17:124] And as when the sun is on the point of rising, even before his rays appear the light of the day groweth bright; so also when then the Sun of Righteousness was about to come, death henceforth began to withdraw himself.

[17:125] What could be more splendid than that theatre? What more conspicuous than that victory? What more signal than those new trophies of theirs?  The same thing is done in our time also.

[17:126] Even now is there a king of the Babylonish furnace, even now he kindles a flame fiercer than that.

[17:127] There is even now such an image, and one who giveth command to admire it.

[17:128] At his side are satraps and soldiers and bewitching music.

[17:129] And many gaze in admiration upon this image, so varied, so great.

[17:130] For somewhat of the same kind of thing as that image is covetousness, which doth not despise even iron, but unlike as the materials are whereof it is composed, it giveth command to admire all, both brass and iron, and things much more ordinary than they.

[17:131] But as these things are, so also even now are there some who are emulous of these children: who say, "thy gods we serve not, and thine images we worship not;" but both the furnace of poverty we endure and all other distress, for the sake of God's laws".

[17:132] And the wealthy for their part, even as those at that time, oftentimes, worship this image too and are burnt.

[17:133] But those who possess nothing despite even this, and although in poverty, are more in the dew than those who live in affluence.

[17:134] Even as at that time they who cast into the fire were burnt up; but those in the midst of it found themselves in dew as it were rain.

[17:135] Then also that tyrant was more burnt up with the flame, his wrath kindling him violently, than those children.

[17:136] As to them, the fire had no power even to touch the ends of their hair: but more fiercely than that fire did wrath burn up his mind.

[17:137] For consider what a thing it was that with so many to look on, he should be scorned by captive children.

[17:138] And it was a sign that his taking their city also had not been through his own might, but by reason of the sin of the multitude among them.

[17:139] Since if he had not the power to overcome these men in chains, and that when they were cast into a furnace, how could he have overcome the Jews in regular warfare, had they been all such as these? From which it is plain that the sins of the multitude betrayed the city.

[17:140] But mark also the children's freedom from vain-glory.

[17:141] For they did not leap into the furnace, but they kept beforehand the commandment of Christ where he says, (St.

[17:142] Matt.

[17:143] xxvi.

[17:144] ) "Pray that ye enter not into temptation".

[17:145] Neither did they shrink when they were brought to it; but stood in the midst nobly, neither contending without a summons, nor yet when summoned playing the coward: but ready for everything, and noble, and full of all boldness of speech.

[17:146] But let us hear also what they say, that from this also we may learn their lofty spirit.

[17:147] (Dan.

[17:148] iii.

[17:149] ) "There is a God in heaven able to deliver us:" they take no care for themselves, but even when about to be burned the glory of God is all their thought.

[17:150] For what they say comes to this, "Lest perchance if we are burnt thou shouldest charge God with weakness, we now declare unto thee accurately our whole doctrine.

[17:151] "There is a God in heaven," not such as this image here on earth, this lifeless and mute thing, but able to snatch even from the midst of the burning fiery furnace.

[17:152] Condemn him not then of weakness for permitting us to fall into it.

[17:153] So powerful is He that after our fall, He is able to snatch us out again out of the flame.

[17:154] "But if not, be it known unto thee, O king, that we will not serve thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set up".

[17:155] Observe that they by a special dispensation are ignorant of the future: for if they had foreknown, there would have been nothing wonderful in their doing what they did.

[17:156] For what marvel is it if when they had a guarantee for safety, they defied all terrors? Then God indeed would have been glorified in that He was able to deliver from the furnace: but they would not have been wondered at, inasmuch as they would not have cast themselves into any dangers.

[17:157] For this cause He suffered them to be ignorant of the future that He might glorify them the more.

[17:158] And as they cautioned (ἠσψαλίξοντο) the king that he was not to condemn God of weakness though they might be burnt, so God accomplished both purposes; the shewing forth His own power and the causing the zeal of the children to appear more conspicuous.

[17:159] From whence then arose their doubting and their not feeling confident that they should at all events be preserved? Because they esteemed themselves assuredly too mean, and unworthy of such a benefit.

[17:160] And to prove that I say not this upon conjecture; when they fell into the furnace, they bewailed themselves after this sort, saying, (Song of the three Children vv.

[17:161] ,.

[17:162] ) "We have sinned, we have done iniquity, we cannot open our mouth".

[17:163] And therefore they said, "But if not".

[17:164] But if they did not plainly say this, namely, "God is able to deliver us; but if he deliver us not, for our sin's sake He will not deliver us;" wonder not at it.

[17:165] For they would have seemed to the barbarians to be sheltering the weakness of God under the pretext of their own sins.

[17:166] Wherefore His power only is what they speak of: the reason they allege not.

[17:167] And besides, they were well disciplined not to be over-curious about the judgments of God.

[17:168] With these words then, they entered into the fire; and they neither cast insult upon the king, nor overturned the statue.

[17:169] For such should the courageous man be, temperate and mild; and that especially in dangers; that he may not seem to go forth to such contests in wrath and vain-glory; but with fortitude and self-possession.

[17:170] For whoso deals insolently undergoes the suspicion of those faults: but he that endures, and is forced into the struggle, and goes through the trial with meekness, is not only admired as brave, but his self-possession also and consideration cause him to be no less extolled.

[17:171] And this is what they did at that time; shewing forth all fortitude and gentleness, and doing nothing for reward nor for recompense or return.

[17:172] "'Though He be not willing 'so it stands' to deliver us, we will not serve thy gods:' for we have already our recompense in that we are counted worthy to be kept from all impiety, and for that end to give our bodies to be burned".

[17:173] We then also having already our recompense, (for indeed we have it in that we have been vouchsafed the full knowledge of Him, vouch-safed to be made members of Christ,) let us take care that we make them not members of an harlot.

[17:174] For with this most tremendous saying we must conclude our discourse, in order that having the fear of the threat in full efficacy, we may remain purer than gold, this fear helping to make us so.

[17:175] For so shall we be able, delivered from all fornication, to see Christ.

[17:176] Whom God grant us all to behold with boldness at that day, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ; to Whom be the glory, for evermore, Amen.

[18:1] Homily XIX.

[18:2] Cor.

[18:3] vii.

[18:4] ,  Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote to me: it is good for a man not to touch a woman.

[18:5] But because of fornications, let each man have his own wife; and let each woman have her own husband.

[18:6] Having corrected the three heaviest things laid to their charge, one, the distraction of the Church, another, about the fornicator, a third, about the covetous person, he thenceforth uses a milder sort of speech.

[18:7] And he interposes some exhortation and advice about marriage and virginity, giving the hearers some respite from more unpleasant subjects.

[18:8] But in the second Epistle he does the contrary; he begins from the milder topics, and ends with the more distressing.

[18:9] And here also, after he has finished his discourse about virginity, he again launches forth into matter more akin to reproof; not setting all down in regular order, but varying his discourse in either kind, as the occasion required and the exigency of the matters in hand.

[18:10] Wherefore he says, "Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote unto me".

[18:11] For they had written to him, "Whether it was right to abstain from one's wife, or not:" and writing back in answer to this and giving rules about marriage, he introduces also the discourse concerning virginity: "It is good for a man not to touch a woman".

[18:12] "For if," says he, "thou enquire what is the excellent and greatly superior course, it is better not to have any connection whatever with a woman: but if you ask what is safe and helpful to thine own infirmity, be connected by marriage".

[18:13] But since it was likely, as also happens now, that the husband might be willing but the wife not, or perhaps the reverse, mark how he discusses each case.

[18:14] Some indeed say that this discourse was addressed by him to priests.

[18:15] But I, judging from what follows, could not affirm that it was so: since he would not have given his advice in general terms.

[18:16] For if he were writing these things only for the priests, he would have said, "It is good for the teacher not to touch a woman".

[18:17] But now he has made it of universal application, saying, "It is good for a man;" not for priest only.

[18:18] And again, "Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife".

[18:19] He said not, "You who are a priest and teacher," but indefinitely.

[18:20] And the whole of his speech goes on entirely in the same tones.

[18:21] And in saying, "Because of fornications, let every man have his own wife" by the very cause alleged for the concession he guides men to continence.

[18:22] Ver.

[18:23] "Let the husband pay the wife the honor due to her: in like manner the wife the husband".

[18:24] Now what is the meaning of "the due honor? The wife hath not power over her own body;" but is both the slave and the mistress of the husband.

[18:25] And if you decline the service which is due, you have offended God.

[18:26] But if thou wish to withdraw thyself, it must be with the husband's permission, though it be but a for short time.

[18:27] For this is why he calls the matter a debt, to shew that no one is master of himself but that they are servants to each other.

[18:28] When therefore thou seest an harlot tempting thee, say, "My body is not mine, but my wife's".

[18:29] The same also let the woman say to those who would undermine her chastity, "My body is not mine, but my husband's".

[18:30] Now if neither husband nor wife hath power even over their own body, much less have they over their property.

[18:31] Hear ye, all that have husbands and all that have wives: that if you must not count your body your own, much less your money.

[18:32] Elsewhere I grant He gives to the husband abundant precedence, both in the New Testament, and the Old saying, (ἡ ἀποστρόφή σου, LXX.

[18:33] Gen.

[18:34] iii.

[18:35] ) "Thy turning shall be towards thy husband, and he shall rule over thee".

[18:36] Paul doth so too by making a distinction thus, and writing, (Ephes.

[18:37] v.

[18:38] ,.

[18:39] ) "Husbands, love your wives; and let the wife see that she reverence her husband".

[18:40] But in this place we hear no more of greater and less, but it is one and the same right.

[18:41] Now why is this? Because his speech was about chastity.

[18:42] "In all other things," says he, "let the husband have the prerogative; but not so where the question is about chastity".

[18:43] "The husband hath no power over his own body, neither the wife".

[18:44] There is great equality of honor, and no prerogative.

[18:45] Ver.

[18:46] "Defraud ye not one the other, except it be by consent".

[18:47] What then can this mean? "Let not the wife," says he, "exercise continence, if the husband be unwilling; nor yet the husband without the wife's consent".

[18:48] Why so? Because great evils spring from this sort of continence.

[18:49] For adulteries and fornications and the ruin of families have often arisen from hence.

[18:50] For if when men have their own wives they commit fornication, much more if you defraud them of this consolation.

[18:51] And well says he, "Defraud not; fraud" here, and "debt" above, that he might shew the strictness of the right of dominion in question.

[18:52] For that one should practice continence against the will of the other is "defrauding;" but not so, with the other's consent: any more than I count myself defrauded, if after persuading me you take away any thing of mine.

[18:53] Since only he defrauds who takes against another's will and by force.

[18:54] A thing which many women do, working sin rather than righteousness, and thereby becoming accountable for the husband's uncleanness, and rending all asunder.

[18:55] Whereas they should value concord above all things, since this is more important than all beside.

[18:56] We will, if you please, consider it with a view to actual cases.

[18:57] Thus, suppose a wife and husband, and let the wife be continent, without consent of her husband; well then, if hereupon he commit fornication, or though abstaining from fornication fret and grow restless and be heated and quarrel and give all kind of trouble to his wife; where is all the gain of the fasting and the continence, a breach being made in love? There is none.

[18:58] For what strange reproaches, how much trouble, how great a war must of course arise! since when in an house man and wife are at variance, the house will be no better off than a ship in a storm when the master is upon ill terms with the man at the head.

[18:59] Wherefore he saith, "Defraud not one another, unless it be by consent for a season, that ye may give yourselves unto prayer".

[18:60] It is prayer with unusual earnestness which he here means.

[18:61] For if he is forbidding those who have intercourse with one another to pray, how could "pray without ceasing" have any place? It is possible then to live with a wife and yet give heed unto prayer.

[18:62] But by continence prayer is made more perfect.

[18:63] For he did not say merely, "That ye may pray;" but, "That ye may give yourselves unto it;" as though what he speaks of might cause not uncleanness but much occupation.

[18:64] "And may be together again, that Satan tempt you not".

[18:65] Thus lest it should seem to be a matter of express enactment, he adds the reason.

[18:66] And what is it? "That Satan tempt you not".

[18:67] And that you may understand that it is not the devil only who causeth this crime, I mean adultery, he adds, "because of your incontinency".

[18:68] "But this I say by way of permission, not of commandment.

[18:69] For I would that all men were even as I myself; in a state of continence".

[18:70] This he doth in many places when he is advising about difficult matters; he brings forward himself, and says, "Be ye imitators of me".

[18:71] "Howbeit each man hath his own gift from God, one after this manner, and another after that".

[18:72] Thus since he had heavily charged them saying, "for your incontinence," he again comforteth them by the words, "each one hath his own gift of God;" not declaring that towards that virtue there is no need of zeal on our part, but, as I was saying before, to comfort them.

[18:73] For if it be a "gift," and man contributes nothing thereunto, how sayest thou, "But (v.

[18:74] ) I say to the unmarried and to widows, it is good for them if they abide even as I: (v.

[18:75] ) but if they have not continency let them marry?" Do you see the strong sense of Paul how he both signifies that continence is better, and yet puts no force on the person who cannot attain to it; fearing lest some offence arise?  "For it is better to marry than to burn".

[18:76] He indicates how great is the tyranny of concupiscence.

[18:77] What he means is something like this: "If you have to endure much violence and burning desire, withdraw yourself from your pains and toils, lest haply you be subverted".

[18:78] Ver.

[18:79] "But to the married I give charge, yet not I, but the Lord".

[18:80] Because it is a law expressly appointed by Christ which he is about to read to them about the "not putting away a wife without fornication; "(S.

[18:81] Matt.

[18:82] v.

[18:83] , xix.

[18:84] ; S.

[18:85] Mark x.

[18:86] ; S.

[18:87] Luke xvi.

[18:88] ) therefore he says, "Not I".

[18:89] True it is what was before spoken though it were not expressly stated, yet it also is His decree.

[18:90] But this, you see, He had delivered in express words.

[18:91] So that the words "I and not I" have this difference of meaning.

[18:92] For that you might not imagine even his own words to be human, therefore he added, "For I think that I also have the Spirit of God".

[18:93] Now what is that which "to the married the Lord commanded? That the wife depart not from her husband: (v.

[18:94] ) but if she depart, let her remain unmarried, or be reconciled unto her husband".

[18:95] Here, seeing that both on the score of continence and other pretexts, and because of infirmities of temper, (μικροψυχίας.

[18:96] ) it fell out that separations took place: it were better, he says, that such things should not be at all; but however if they take place, let the wife remain with her husband, if not to cohabit with him, yet so as not to introduce any other to be her husband.

[18:97] Ver.

[18:98] "But to the rest speak I, not the Lord.

[18:99] If any brother have a wife that believeth not, and she is content to dwell with him, let him not leave her.

[18:100] And if any woman hath an husband that believeth not, and he is content to dwell with her, let her not leave him".

[18:101] For as when discoursing about separating from fornicators, he made the matter easy by the correction which he applied to his words, saying, "Howbeit, not altogether with the fornicators of this world;" so also in this case he provideth for the abundant easiness of the duty, saying, "If any wife have a husband, or husband a wife, that believeth not, let him not leave her".

[18:102] What sayest thou? "If he be an unbeliever, let him remain with the wife, but not if he be a fornicator? And yet fornication is a less sin than unbelief".

[18:103] I grant, fornication is a less sin: but God spares thine infirmities extremely.

[18:104] And this is what He doth about the sacrifice, saying, (S.

[18:105] Matt.

[18:106] v.

[18:107] ) "Leave the sacrifice, and be reconciled to thy brother".

[18:108] This also in the case of the man who owed ten thousand talents.

[18:109] For him too He did not punish for owing him ten thousand talents, but for demanding back a hundred pence from his fellow-servant He took vengeance on him.

[18:110] Then lest the woman might fear, as though she became unclean because of intercourse with her husband, he says, "For the unbelieving husband is sanctified in the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified in the husband".

[18:111] And yet, if "he that is joined to an harlot is one body," it is quite clear that the woman also who is joined to an idolater is one body.

[18:112] Well: it is one body; nevertheless she becomes not unclean, but the cleanness of the wife overcomes the uncleanness of the husband; and again, the cleanness of the believing husband overcomes the uncleanness of the unbelieving wife.

[18:113] How then in this case is the uncleanness overcome, and therefore the intercourse allowed; while in the woman who prostitutes herself, the husband is not condemned in casting her out? Because here there is hope that the lost member may be saved through the marriage; but in the other case the marriage has already been dissolved; and there again both are corrupted; but here the fault is in one only of the two.

[18:114] I mean something like this: she that has been guilty of fornication is utterly abominable: if then "he that is joined to an harlot is one body," he also becomes abominable by having connection with an harlot; wherefore all the purity flits away.

[18:115] But in the case before us it is not so.

[18:116] But how? The idolater is unclean but the woman is not unclean.

[18:117] For if indeed she were a partner with him in that wherein he is unclean, I mean his impiety, she herself would also become unclean.

[18:118] But now the idolater is unclean in one way, and the wife holds communion with him in another wherein he is not unclean.

[18:119] For marriage and mixture of bodies is that wherein the communion consists.

[18:120] Again, there is a hope that this man may be reclaimed by his wife for she is made completely his own: but for the other it is not very easy.

[18:121] For how will she who dishonored him in former times and became another's and destroyed the rights of marriage, have power to reclaim him whom she had wronged; him, moreover, who still remains to her as an alien?  Again in that case, after the fornication the husband is not a husband: but here, although the wife be an idolatress, the husband's rights are not destroyed.

[18:122] However, he doth not simply recommend cohabitation with the unbeliever, but with the qualification that he wills it.

[18:123] Wherefore he said, "And he himself be content to dwell with her".

[18:124] For, tell me, what harm is there when the duties of piety remain unimpaired and there are good hopes about the unbeliever, that those already joined should so abide and not bring in occasions of unnecessary warfare? For the question now is not about those who have never yet come together, but about those who are already joined.

[18:125] He did not say, If any one wish to take an unbelieving wife, but, "If any one hath an unbelieving wife".

[18:126] Which means, If any after marrying or being married have received the word of godliness, and then the other party which had continued in unbelief still yearn for them to dwell together, let not the marriage be broken off.

[18:127] "For," saith he, "the unbelieving husband is sanctified in the wife".

[18:128] So great is the superabundance of thy purity.

[18:129] What then, is the Greek holy? Certainly not: for he said not, He is holy; but, "He is sanctified in his wife".

[18:130] And this he said, not to signify that he is holy, but to deliver the woman as completely as possible from her fear and lead the man to desire the truth.

[18:131] For the uncleanness is not in the bodies wherein there is communion, but in the mind and the thoughts.

[18:132] And here follows the proof; namely, that if thou continuing unclean have offspring, the child, not being of thee alone, is of course unclean or half clean.

[18:133] But now it is not unclean.

[18:134] To which effect he adds, "else were your children unclean; but now are they holy;" that is, not unclean.

[18:135] But the Apostle calls them, "holy," by the intensity of the expression again casting out the dread arising from that sort of suspicion.

[18:136] Ver.

[18:137] "Yet if the unbelieving departeth, let him depart," for in this case the matter is no longer fornication.

[18:138] But what is the meaning of, "if the unbelieving departeth?" For instance, if he bid thee sacrifice and take part in his ungodliness on account of thy marriage, or else part company; it were better the marriage were annulled, and no breach made in godliness.

[18:139] Wherefore he adds, "A brother is not under bondage, nor yet a sister, in such cases".

[18:140] If day by day he buffet thee and keep up combats on this account, it is better to separate.

[18:141] For this is what he glances at, saying, "But God hath called us in peace".

[18:142] For it is the other party who furnished the ground of separation, even as he did who committed uncleanness.

[18:143] Ver.

[18:144] "For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thine husband?" This again refers to that expression, "let her not leave him".

[18:145] That is, "if he makes no disturbance, remain," saith he, "for there is even profit in this; remain and advise and give counsel and persuade".

[18:146] For no teacher will have such power to prevail (Reg.

[18:147] πεῖσαι.

[18:148] Bened.

[18:149] ἰσχὺσαι.

[18:150] ) as a wife.

[18:151] And neither, on one hand, doth he lay any necessity upon her and absolutely demand the point of her, that he may not again do what would be too painful; nor, on the other, doth he tell her to despair: but he leaves the matter in suspense through the uncertainty of the future, saying, "For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband? or how knowest thou, O husband whether thou shalt save thy wife?"   And again, ver.

[18:152] "Only as God hath distributed to each man, as the Lord hath called each, so let him walk.

[18:153] Was any one called being circumcised? let him not become uncircumcised.

[18:154] Was any called in uncircumcision? let him not be circumcised.

[18:155] Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing; but the keeping of the commandments of God.

[18:156] Let each man abide in that calling wherein he was called.

[18:157] Wast thou called, being a slave? Care not for it".

[18:158] These things contribute nothing unto faith, saith he.

[18:159] Be not then contentious neither be troubled; for the faith hath cast out all these things.

[18:160] "Let each man abide in that calling wherein he was called.

[18:161] Hast thou been called, having an unbelieving wife? Continue to have her.

[18:162] Cast not out thy wife for the faith's sake.

[18:163] Hast thou been called, being a slave? Care not for it.

[18:164] Continue to be a slave.

[18:165] Hast thou been called, being in uncircumcision? Remain uncircumcised.

[18:166] Being circumcised, didst thou become a believer? Continue circumcised.

[18:167] For this is the meaning of, "As God hath distributed unto each man".

[18:168] For these are no hindrances to piety.

[18:169] Thou art called, being a slave; another, with an unbelieving wife; another, being circumcised.

[18:170] Astonishing! where has he put slavery? As circumcision profits not: and uncircumcision does no harm; so neither doth slavery, nor yet liberty.

[18:171] And that he might point out this with surpassing clearness, he says, "But even (Αλλ' εὶ καὶ δυνάσαι) if thou canst become free, use it rather:" that is, rather continue a slave.

[18:172] Now upon what possible ground does he tell the person who might be set free to remain a slave? He means to point out that slavery is no harm but rather an advantage.

[18:173] Now we are not ignorant that some say, the words, "use it rather," are spoken with regard to liberty: interpreting it, "if thou canst become free, become free".

[18:174] But the expression would be very contrary to Paul's manner if he intended this.

[18:175] For he would not, when consoling the slave and signifying that he was in no respect injured, have told him to get free.

[18:176] Since perhaps some one might say, "What then, if I am not able? I am an injured and degraded person".

[18:177] This then is not what he says: but as I said, meaning to point out that a man gets nothing by being made free, he says, "Though thou hast it in thy power to be made free, remain rather in slavery".

[18:178] Next he adds also the cause; "For he that was called in the Lord being a bondservant, is the Lord's free man: likewise he that was called, being free, is Christ's bondservant".

[18:179] "For," saith he, "in the things that relate to Christ, both are equal: and like as thou art the slave of Christ, so also is thy master.

[18:180] How then is the slave a free man? Because He has freed thee not only from sin, but also from outward slavery while continuing a slave.

[18:181] For he suffers not the slave to be a slave, not even though he be a man abiding in slavery: and this is the great wonder.

[18:182] But how is the slave a free man while continuing a slave? When he is freed from passions and the diseases of the mind: when he looks down upon riches and wrath and all other the like passions.

[18:183] Ver.

[18:184] "Ye were bought with a price: become not bondservants of men".

[18:185] This saying is addressed not to slaves only but also to free men.

[18:186] For it is possible for one who is a slave not to be a slave; and for one who is a freeman to be a slave.

[18:187] "And how can one be a slave and not a slave?" When he doeth all for God: when he feigns nothing, and doeth nothing out of eye-service towards men: that is how one that is a slave to men can be free.

[18:188] Or again, how doth one that is free become a slave? When he serves men in any evil service, either for gluttony or desire of wealth or for office' sake.

[18:189] For such an one, though he be free, is more of a slave than any man.

[18:190] And consider both these points.

[18:191] Joseph was a slave but not a slave to men: wherefore even in slavery he was freer than all that are free.

[18:192] For instance, he yielded not to his mistress; yielded not to the purposes which she who possessed him desired.

[18:193] Again she was free; yet none ever so like a slave, courting and beseeching her own servant.

[18:194] But she prevailed not on him, who was free, to do what he would not.

[18:195] This then was not slavery; but it was liberty of the most exalted kind.

[18:196] For what impediment to virtue had he from his slavery? Let men hear, both slaves and free.

[18:197] Which was the slave? He that was entreated or she that did entreat? She that besought or he that despised her supplication?  In fact, there are limits set to slaves by God Himself; and up to what point one ought to keep them, has also been determined, and to transgress them is wrong.

[18:198] Namely, when your master commands nothing which is unpleasing to God, it is right to follow and to obey; but no farther.

[18:199] For thus the slave becomes free.

[18:200] But if you go further, even though you are free you are become a slave.

[18:201] At least he intimates this, saying, "Be not ye the servants of men".

[18:202] But if this be not the meaning, if he bade them forsake their masters and strive contentiously to become free, in what sense did he exhort them, saying, "Let each one remain in the calling in which he is called?" And in another place, ( Tim.

[18:203] vi.

[18:204] ,.

[18:205] ) "As many servants as are under the yoke, let them count their own masters worthy of all honor; and those that have believing masters, let them not despise them, because they are brethren who partake of the benefit".

[18:206] And writing to the Ephesians also and to the Colossians, he ordains and exacts the same rules.

[18:207] Whence it is plain that it is not this slavery which he annuls, but that which caused as it is by vice befalls free men also: and this is the worst kind of slavery, though he be a free man who is in bondage to it.

[18:208] For what profit had Joseph's brethren of their freedom? Were they not more servile than all slaves; both speaking lies to their father, and to the merchants using false pretences, as well as to their brother? But not such was the free man: rather every where and in all things he was true.

[18:209] And nothing had power to enslave him, neither chain nor bondage nor the love of his mistress nor his being in a strange land.

[18:210] But he abode free every where.

[18:211] For this is liberty in the truest sense when even in bondage it shines through.

[18:212] Such a thing is Christianity; in slavery it bestows freedom.

[18:213] And as that which is by nature an invulnerable body then shews itself to be invulnerable when having received a dart it suffers no harm; so also he that is strictly free then shows himself, when even under masters he is not enslaved.

[18:214] For this cause his bidding is, "remain a slave".

[18:215] But if it is impossible for one who is a slave to be a Christian such as he ought to be, the Greeks will condemn true religion of great weakness: whereas if they can be taught that slavery in no way impairs godliness, they will admire our doctrine.

[18:216] For if death hurt us not, nor scourges, nor chains, much less slavery.

[18:217] Fire and iron and tyrannies innumerable and diseases and poverty and wild beasts and countless things more dreadful than these, have not been able to injure the faithful; nay, they have made them even mightier.

[18:218] And how shall slavery be able to hurt? It is not slavery itself, beloved, that hurts; but the real slavery is that of sin.

[18:219] And if thou be not a slave in this sense, be bold and rejoice.

[18:220] No one shall have power to do thee any wrong, having the temper which cannot be enslaved.

[18:221] But if thou be a slave to sin, even though thou be ten thousand times free thou hast no good of thy freedom.

[18:222] For, tell me, what profit is it when, though not in bondage to a man, thou liest down in subjection to thy passions? Since men indeed often know how to spare; but those masters are never satiated with thy destruction.

[18:223] Art thou in bondage to a man? Why, thy master also is slave to thee, in arranging about thy food, in taking care of thy health and in looking after thy shoes and all the other things.

[18:224] And thou dost not fear so much less thou shouldest offend thy master, as he fears lest any of those necessaries should fail thee.

[18:225] "But he sits down, while thou standest".

[18:226] And what of that? Since this may be said of thee as well as of him.

[18:227] Often, at least, when thou art lying down and sleeping sweetly, he is not only standing, but undergoing endless discomforts in the market-place; and he lies awake more painfully than thou.

[18:228] For instance; what did Joseph suffer from his mistress to be compared with what she suffered from her evil desire? For he indeed did not the things which she wished to put upon him; but she performed every thing which her mistress ordered her, I mean her spirit of unchastity: which left not off until it had put her to open shame.

[18:229] What master commands such things? what savage tyrant? "Intreat thy slave," that is the word: "flatter the person bought with thy money, supplicate the captive; even if he reject thee with disgust, again besiege him: even if thou speakest to him oftentimes, and he consent not, watch for his being alone, and force him, and become an object of derision".

[18:230] What can be more dishonorable, what more shameful, than these words? "And if even by these means you make no progress, why, accuse him falsely and deceive your husband".

[18:231] Mark how mean, how shameful are the commands, how unmerciful and savage and frantic.

[18:232] What command does the master ever lay on his slave, such as those which her wantonness then laid upon that royal woman? And yet she dare not disobey.

[18:233] But Joseph underwent nothing of this sort, but every thing on the contrary which brought glory and honor.

[18:234] Would you like to see yet another man under severe orders from a hard mistress, and without spirit to disobey any of them? Consider Cain, what commands were laid on him by his envy.

[18:235] She ordered him to slay his brother, to lie unto God, to grieve his father, to cast off shame; and he did it all, and in nothing refused to obey.

[18:236] And why marvel that over a single person so great should be the power of this mistress? She hath often destroyed entire nations.

[18:237] For instance, the Midianitish women took the Jews, and all but bound them in captivity; their own beauty kindling desire, was the means of their vanquishing that whole nation.

[18:238] Paul then to cast out this sort of slavery, said, "Become not servants of men;" that is, "Obey not men commanding unreasonable things: nay, obey not yourselves".

[18:239] Then having raised up their mind and made it mount on high, he says,   Ver.

[18:240] "Now concerning virgins.

[18:241] I have no commandment of the Lord; but I give my judgment, as one that hath obtained mercy of the Lord to be faithful".

[18:242] Advancing on his way in regular order, he proceeds next to speak concerning virginity.

[18:243] For after that he had exercised and trained them, in his words concerning continence, he goes forth towards what is greater, saying, "I have no commandment, but I esteem it to be good".

[18:244] For what reason? For the self-same reason as he had mentioned respecting continence.

[18:245] Ver.

[18:246] "Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not to be loosed.

[18:247] Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife".

[18:248] These words carry no contradiction to what had been said before but rather the most entire agreement with them.

[18:249] For he says in that place also, "Except it be by consent:" as here he says, "Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not separation".

[18:250] This is no contradiction.

[18:251] For its being against consent makes a dissolution: but if with consent both live continently, it is no dissolution.

[18:252] Then, lest this should seem to be laying down a law, he subjoins, (v.

[18:253] ) "but if thou marry, thou hast not sinned".

[18:254] He next alleges the existing state of things, "the present distress, the shortness of the time," and "the affliction".

[18:255] For marriage draws along with it many things, which indeed he hath glanced at, as well here as also in the discourse about continence: there, by saying, "the wife hath not power over herself;" and here, by the expression, "Thou art bound".

[18:256] "But if and thou marry, thou hast not sinned".

[18:257] He is not speaking about her who hath made choice of virginity, for if it comes to that, she hath sinned.

[18:258] Since if the widows are condemned for having to do with second marriages after they have once chosen widowhood, much more the virgins.

[18:259] "But such shall have trouble in the flesh".

[18:260] "And pleasure too," you will say: but observe how he curtails this by the shortness of the time, saying, (v.

[18:261] ) "the time is shortened;" that is, "we are exhorted to depart now and go forth, but thou art running further in".

[18:262] And yet even although marriage had no troubles, even so we ought to press on towards things to come.

[18:263] But when it hath affliction too, what need to draw on one's self an additional burden.

[18:264] What occasion to take up such a load, when even after taking it you must use it as having it not? For "those even that have wives must be," he saith, "as though they had none".

[18:265] Then, having interposed something about the future, he brings back his speech to the present.
