[30:155] For so this man takes no thought nor anxiety to be himself rid of this deep slumber, but doth every thing to supplant and throw down him that is flying towards heaven, becoming an exact emulator of the devil: since he too, seeing man in paradise, sought not to change his own condition, but to cast him out of paradise.

[30:156] And again, seeing him seated in heaven and the rest hastening thither, he holds to the same plan, supplanting them who are hastening thither and hereby heaping up the furnace more abundantly for himself.

[30:157] For in every instance this happens: both he that is envied, if he be vigilant, becoming more eminent; and he that is envious, accumulating to himself more evils.

[30:158] Thus also Joseph became eminent, thus Aaron the priest: the conspiracy of the envious caused God once and again to give His suffrage for him, and was the occasion of the rod's budding.

[30:159] Thus Jacob attained his abundant wealth and all those other blessings.

[30:160] Thus the envious pierce themselves through with ten thousand evils.

[30:161] Knowing as we do all these things, let us flee such emulation.

[30:162] For wherefore, tell me, enviest thou? Because thy brother hath received spiritual grace? And from whom did he receive it? answer me.

[30:163] Was it not from God? Clearly then He is the object of the enmity to Which thou art committing thyself, He the bestower of the gift.

[30:164] Seest thou which way the evil is tending, and with what sort of a point it is crowning the heap of thy sins; and how deep the pit of vengeance which it is digging for thee?  Let us flee it, then, beloved, and neither envy others, nor fail to pray for our enviers and do all we can to extinguish their passion: neither let us feel as the unthinking do who being minded to exact punishment of them, do all in their power to light up their flame.

[30:165] But let not us do so; rather let us weep for them and lament.

[30:166] For they are the injured persons, having continual worm gnawing through their heart, and collecting a fountain of poison more bitter than any gall.

[30:167] Come now, let us beseech the merciful God, both to change their state of feeling and that we may never fall into that disease: since heaven is indeed inaccessible to him that hath this wasting sore, and before heaven too, even this present life is not worth living in.

[30:168] For not so thoroughly are timber and wool wont to be eaten through by moth and worm abiding therein, as doth the fever of envy devour the very bones of the envious and destroy all self-command in their soul.

[30:169] In order then that we may deliver both ourselves and others from these innumerable woes, let us expel from within us this evil fever, this that is more grievous than any gangrene: that having regained spiritual strength, we may both finish the present course and obtain the future crowns; unto which may we all attain, by the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

[31:1] Homily XXXII.

[31:2] Cor.

[31:3] xii.

[31:4] Now ye are the body of Christ and severally members thereof.

[31:5] For lest any should say, "What is the example of the body to us? since the body is a slave to nature but our good deeds are of choice;" he applies it to our own concerns; and to signify that we ought to have the same concord of design as they have from nature, he saith, "Now ye are the body of Christ".

[31:6] But if our body ought not to be divided, much less the body of Christ, and so much less as grace is more powerful than nature.

[31:7] But what is the expression, "severally?" "So far at least as appertaineth to you; and so far as naturally a part should be built up from you".

[31:8] For because he had said, "the body," whereas the whole body was not the Corinthian Church, but the Church in every part of the world, therefore he said, "severally:" i-e:, the Church amongst you is a part of the Church existing every where and of the body which is made up of all the Churches: so that not only with yourselves alone, but also with the whole Church throughout the world, ye ought to be at peace, if at least ye be members of the whole body.

[31:9] Ver.

[31:10] "And God hath set some in the Church: first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, divers kinds of tongues".

[31:11] Thus what I spake of before, this also he now doth.

[31:12] Because they thought highly of themselves in respect of the tongues he sets it last every where.

[31:13] For the terms, "first" and "secondly," are not used by him here at random, but in order by enumeration to point out the more honorable and the inferior.

[31:14] Wherefore also he set the apostles first who had all the gifts in themselves.

[31:15] And he said not, "God hath set certain in the Church, apostles" simply, "or prophets," but he employs "first, second," and "third," signifying that same thing which I told you of.

[31:16] "Secondly, prophets".

[31:17] For they used to prophesy, as the daughters of Philip, as Agabus, as these very persons among the Corinthians, of whom he saith, "Let the prophets speak, two or three".

[31:18] (c.

[31:19] xiv.

[31:20] ) And writing also to Timothy, he said, "Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy".

[31:21] ( Tim.

[31:22] iv.

[31:23] ) And they were much more many that prophesied.

[31:24] And if Christ saith, "The Law and the Prophets prophesied until John," (S.

[31:25] Matt.

[31:26] xi.

[31:27] ) He saith it of those prophets who before proclaimed His coming.

[31:28] "Thirdly, teachers".

[31:29] For he that prophesieth speaks all things from the Spirit; but he that teacheth sometimes discourses also out of his own mind.

[31:30] Wherefore also he said, "Let the elders that rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially they who labor in the word and in teaching:" ( Tim.

[31:31] v.

[31:32] ) whereas he that speaks all things by the Spirit doth not labor.

[31:33] This accordingly is the reason why he set him after the prophet, because the one is wholly a gift but the other is also man's labor.

[31:34] For he speaks many things of his own mind, agreeing however with the sacred Scriptures.

[31:35] "Then miracles, then gifts of healings".

[31:36] Seest thou how he again divides the healings from the power, which also he did before.

[31:37] For the power is more than the healing: since he that hath power both punishes and heals, but he that hath the gift of healings doeth cures only.

[31:38] And observe how excellent the order he made use of, when he set the prophecy before the miracles and the healings.

[31:39] For above when he said, "To one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, and to another the word of knowledge," he spake, not setting them in order, but indifferently.

[31:40] Here, on the other hand, he sets a first and a second rank.

[31:41] Wherefore then doth he set prophecy first? Because even in the old covenant the matter has this order.

[31:42] For example, when Isaiah was discoursing with the Jews, and exhibiting a demonstration of the power of God, and bringing forward the evidence of the worthlessness of the demons, he stated this also as the greater evidence of his divinity, his foretelling things to come.

[31:43] (Is.

[31:44] xli.

[31:45] ,.

[31:46] ) And Christ Himself after working so many signs saith that this was no small sign of His divinity: and continually adds, "But these things have I told you, that when it is come to pass, ye may believe that I am He".

[31:47] (S.

[31:48] John xiii.

[31:49] ; xiv.

[31:50] ; xvi.

[31:51] )  "Well then; the gifts of healing are justly inferior to prophecy.

[31:52] But why likewise to teaching?" Because it is not the same thing to declare the word of preaching and sow piety in the hearts of the hearers, as it is to work miracles: since these are done merely for the sake of that.

[31:53] When therefore any one teaches both by word and life, he is greater than all.

[31:54] For those he calls emphatically teachers, who both teach by deeds and instruct in word.

[31:55] For instance: this made the Apostles themselves to become Apostles.

[31:56] And those gifts certain others also, of no great worth, received in the beginning, as they who said, "Lord, did we not prophesy by Thy Name, and do mighty works?" and after this were told, "I never knew you; depart from Me, ye that work iniquity".

[31:57] (S.

[31:58] Matt.

[31:59] vii.

[31:60] ) But this twofold mode of teaching, I mean that by deeds and by words, no bad man would ever undertake.

[31:61] As to his setting the prophets first marvel not at it.

[31:62] For he is not speaking of prophets simply, but of those who by prophecy do also teach and say every thing to the common benefit: which in proceeding he makes more clear to us.

[31:63] "Helps, governments".

[31:64] What is, "helps?" To support the weak.

[31:65] Is this then a gift, tell me? In the first place, this too is of the Gift of God, aptness for a patron's office; the dispensing spiritual things; besides which he calls many even of our own good deeds, "gifts;" not meaning us to lose heart, but showing that in every case we need God's help, and preparing them to be thankful, and thereby making them more forward and stirring up their minds.

[31:66] "Divers kind of tongues".

[31:67] Seest thou where he hath set this gift, and how he every where assigns it the last rank?   Further, since again by this catalogue he had pointed out a great difference, and stirred up the afore-mentioned distemper of those that had lesser gifts, he darts upon them in what follows with great vehemence, because he had already given them those many proofs of their not being left much inferior.

[31:68] What I mean is; because it was likely that on hearing these things they would say, "And why were we not all made Apostles?"—whereas above he had made use of a more soothing tone of discourse, proving at length the necessity of this result, even from the image of the body; for "the body," saith he, "is not one member;" and again, "but if all were one member, where were the body?" and from the fact that they were given for use; for to each one is given "the manifestation of the Spirit," saith he, "to profit withal:" and from all being watered from the same Spirit: and from what is bestowed being a free gift and not a debt; "for there are," saith he, "diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit:" and from the manifestation of the Spirit being made alike through all; for "to each one," saith he, "is given the manifestation through the Spirit:" and from the fact that these things were shaped according to the pleasure of the Spirit and of God; "for all these," saith he, "worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one severally even as he will:" and, "God hath set the members each one of them in the body, even as it pleased Him:" and from the inferior members also being necessary; "for those which seem," saith he, "to be more feeble are necessary:" from their being alike necessary, in that they "from the greater too needing the less: "for the head," saith he, "cannot say to the feet, I have no need of you:" from these latter enjoying even more honor; for "to that which lacketh," saith he, "He hath given more abundant honor:" from the care of them being common and equal; for "for all the members have the same care one for another:" and from there being one honor and one grief of them all; for "whether," saith he, "one member suffereth, all the members suffer with it; or one member is honored, all the members rejoice with it:"—whereas, I say, he had above exhorted them by these topics, here and henceforth he uses language so as to bear them down and rebuke them.

[31:69] For, as I said, it behoves us neither always to exhort people nor always to silence them.

[31:70] Therefore also Paul himself, because he at length exhorted them, doth henceforth vehemently attack them, saying,  Ver.

[31:71] "Are all apostles? are all prophets? have all gifts of healing?"  And he doth not stop at the first and the second gift, but proceeds to the last, either meaning this that all cannot be all things, (even as he there saith, "if all were one member, where were the body?") or establishing some other point also along with these, which may tell in the way of consolation again.

[31:72] What then is this? His signifying that even the lesser gifts are contended for equally with the greater, from the circumstance that not even these were given absolutely to all? For "why," saith he, "dost thou grieve that thou hast not gifts of healing? consider that what thou hast, even though it be less, is oftentimes not possessed by him that hath the greater".

[31:73] Wherefore he saith,  Ver.

[31:74] "Do all speak with tongues? do all interpret?"  For even as the great gifts God hath not vouchsafed all to all men, but to some this, and to others that, so also did He in respect of the less, not proposing these either to all.

[31:75] And this He did, procuring thereby abundant harmony and love, that each one standing in need of the other might be brought close to his brother.

[31:76] This economy He established also in the arts, this also in the elements, this also in the plants, and in our members, and absolutely in all things.

[31:77] Then he subjoins further the most powerful consolation, and sufficient to recover them and quiet their vexed souls.

[31:78] And what is this?  Ver.

[31:79] "Desire earnestly," saith he, "the better gifts.

[31:80] And a still more excellent way show I unto you".

[31:81] Now by saying this, he gently hinted that they were the cause of their own receiving the lesser gifts, and had it in their power, if they would, to receive the greater.

[31:82] For when he saith, "desire earnestly," he demands from them all diligence and desire for spiritual things.

[31:83] And he said not, the greater gifts, but "the better," i-e:, the more useful, those which would profit.

[31:84] And what he means is this: "continue to desire gifts; and I point out to you a fountain of gifts".

[31:85] For neither did he say, "a gift," but "a way," that he might the more extol that which he intends to mention.

[31:86] As if he said, It is not one, or two, or three gifts that I point out to you, but one way which leadeth to all these: and not merely a way, but both "a more excellent way" and one that is open in common to all.

[31:87] For not as the gifts are vouchsafed, to some these, to others those, but not all to all; so also in this case: but it is an universal gift.

[31:88] Wherefore also he invites all to it.

[31:89] "Desire earnestly," saith he, "the better gifts and yet show I unto you a more excellent way;" meaning love towards our neighbor.

[31:90] Then intending to proceed to the discourse concerning it and the encomium of this virtue, he first lowereth these by comparison with it, intimating that they are nothing without it; very considerately.

[31:91] For if he had at once discoursed of love, and having said, "I show unto you a way," had added, "but this is love," and had not conducted his discourse by way of comparison; some might possibly have scoffed at what was said, not understanding clearly the force of the thing spoken of but still gaping after these.

[31:92] Wherefore he doth not at once unfold it, but first excites the hearer by the promise, and saith, "I show unto you a more excellent way," and so having led him to desire it, he doth not even thus straightway proceed to it, but augmenting still further and extending their desire, he discourses first of these very things, and shows that without it they are nothing; reducing them to the greatest necessity of loving one another; seeing also that from neglect of it sprang that which caused all their evils.

[31:93] So that in this respect also it might justly appear great, if the gifts not only brought them not together, but divided them even when united: but this, when many were so divided, would reunite them by virtue of its own and make them one body.

[31:94] This however he doth not say at once, but what they chiefly longed for, that he sets down; as that the thing was a gift and a most excellent way to all the gifts.

[31:95] So that, even if thou wilt not love thy brother on the score of friendship, yet for the sake of obtaining a better sign and an abundant gift, cherish love.

[31:96] And see whence he first begins; from that which was marvellous in their eyes and great, the gift of tongues.

[31:97] And in bringing forward that gift, he mentions it not just in the degree they had it in, but far more.

[31:98] For he did not say, "if I speak with tongues," but,  Chap.

[31:99] xiii.

[31:100] ver.

[31:101] "If I speak with the tongues of men,—"  What is, "of men?" Of all nations in every part of the world.

[31:102] And neither was he content with this amplification, but he likewise uses another much greater, adding the words, "and of angels,—and have not love, I am become sounding brass, or a clanging cymbal".

[31:103] Dost thou see to what point he first exalted the gift, and to what afterwards he lowered and cast it down? For neither did he simply say, "I am nothing," but, "I am become sounding brass," a thing senseless and inanimate.

[31:104] But how "sounding brass?" Emitting a sound indeed, but at random and in vain, and for no good end.

[31:105] Since besides my profiting nothing, I am counted by most men as one giving impertinent trouble, an annoying and wearisome kind of person.

[31:106] Seest thou how one void of love is like to things inanimate and senseless?  Now he here speaks of the "tongues of angels," not investing angels with a body, but what he means is this: "should I even so speak as angels are wont to discourse unto each other, without this I am nothing, nay rather a burden and an annoyance".

[31:107] Thus (to mention one other example) where he saith, "To Him every knee shall bow, of things in heaven and things on earth, and things under the earth," (Philip.

[31:108] ii.

[31:109] ) he doth not say these things as if he attributed to angels knees and bones, far from it, but it is their intense adoration which he intends to shadow out by the fashion amongst us: so also here he calls it "a tongue" not meaning an instrument of flesh, but intending to indicate their converse with each other by the manner which is known amongst us.

[31:110] Then, in order that his discourse may be acceptable, he stops not at the gift of tongues, but proceeds also to the remaining gifts; and having depreciated all in the absence of love, he then depicts her image.

[31:111] And because he preferred to conduct his argument by amplification, he begins from the less and ascends to the greater.

[31:112] For whereas, when he indicated their order, he placed the gift of tongues last, this he now numbers first; by degrees, as I said, ascending to the greater gifts.

[31:113] Thus having spoken of tongues, he proceeds immediately to prophecy; and saith;  Ver.

[31:114] "And if I have the gift of prophecy".

[31:115] And this gift again with an excellency.

[31:116] For as in that case he mentioned not tongues, but the tongues of all mankind, and as he proceeded, those of angels, and then signified that the gift was nothing without love: so also here he mentions not prophecy alone but the very highest prophecy: in having said, "If I have prophecy," he added, "and know all mysteries and all knowledge;" expressing this gift also with intensity.

[31:117] Then after this also he proceeds to the other gifts.

[31:118] And again, that he might not seem to weary them, naming each one of the gifts, he sets down the mother and fountain of all, and this again with an excellency, thus saying, "And if I have all faith".

[31:119] Neither was he content with this, but even that which Christ spake of as greatest, this also he added, saying, "so as to remove mountains and have not love, I am nothing".

[31:120] And consider how again here also he lowers the dignity of the tongues.

[31:121] For whereas in regard of prophecy he signifies the great advantage arising from it, "the understanding mysteries, and having all knowledge;" and in regard of faith, no trifling work, even "the removing mountains;" in respect of tongues, on the other hand, having named the gift itself only, he quits it.

[31:122] But do thou, I pray, consider this also, how in brief he comprehended all gifts when he named prophecy and faith: for miracles are either in words or deeds.

[31:123] And how doth Christ say, that the least degree of faith is the being able to remove a mountain? For as though he were speaking something very small, did He express Himself when He said, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard-seed, ye shall say to this mountain, Remove, and it shall remove;" (S.

[31:124] Matt.

[31:125] xvii.

[31:126] ) whereas Paul saith that this is "all faith".

[31:127] What then must one say? Since this was a great thing, the removing a mountain, therefore also he mentioned it, not as though "all faith" were only able to do this, but since this seemed to be great to the grosser sort because of the bulk of the outward mass, from this also he extols his subject.

[31:128] And what he saith is this:  "If I have all faith, and can remove mountains, but have not love, I am nothing".

[31:129] Ver.

[31:130] "And if I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and if I give my body to be burned, but have not love, it profiteth me nothing".

[31:131] Wonderful amplification! For even these things too he states with another addition: in that he said not, "if I give to the poor the half of my goods," or "two or three parts," but, "though I give all my goods".

[31:132] And he said not, "give," but, "distribute in morsels," so that to the expense may be added the administering also with all care.

[31:133] But not even yet have I pointed out the whole of the excellency, until I bring forward the testimonies of Christ which were spoken concerning almsgiving and death.

[31:134] What then are His testimonies? To the rich man He saith, "If thou wouldest be perfect, sell what thou hast and give to the poor, and come, follow me".

[31:135] (S.

[31:136] Matt.

[31:137] xix.

[31:138] ) And discoursing likewise of love to one's neighbor, He saith, "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man may lay down his life for his friends".

[31:139] (S.

[31:140] John xiv.

[31:141] ) Whence it is evident, that even before God this is greatest of all.

[31:142] But, "I declare," said Paul, "that even if we should lay down life for God's sake, and not merely lay it down, but so as even to be burned, (for this is the meaning of, "if I give my body to be burned,") we shall have no great advantage if we love not our neighbor".

[31:143] Well then, the saying that the gifts are of no great profit without charity is no marvel: since our gifts are a secondary consideration to our way of life.

[31:144] At any rate, many have displayed gifts, and yet on becoming vicious have been punished: as those who "prophesied in His name, and cast out many demons, and wrought many mighty works;" as Judas the traitor: while others, exhibiting as believers a pure life, have needed nothing else in order to their salvation.

[31:145] Wherefore, that the gifts should, as I said, require this, is no marvel: but that an exact life even should avail nothing without it, this is what brings the intensity of expression strongly out and causes great perplexity: especially too when Christ appears to adjudge His great rewards to both these, I mean to the giving up our possessions, and to the perils of martyrdom.

[31:146] For both to the rich man He saith, as I before observed, "If thou wilt be perfect, sell thy goods, and give to the poor, and come, follow me:" and discoursing with the disciples, of martyrdom He saith, "Whosoever shall lose his life for My sake, shall find it;" and, "Whosoever shall confess Me before men, him will I also confess before My Father which is in heaven".

[31:147] For great indeed is the labor of this achievement, and well nigh surpassing nature itself, and this is well known to such as have had these crowns vouchsafed to them.

[31:148] For no language can set it before us: so noble a soul doth the deed belong to and so exceedingly wonderful is it.

[31:149] But nevertheless, this so wonderful thing Paul said was of no great profit without love, even though it have the giving up of one's goods joined with it.

[31:150] Wherefore then hath he thus spoken? This will I now endeavor to explain, first having enquired of this, How is it possible that one who gives all his goods to feed the poor can be wanting in love? I grant, indeed, he that is ready to be burned and hath the gifts, may perhaps possibly not have love: but he who not only gives his goods, but even distributes them in morsels; how hath not he love? What then are we to say? Either that he supposed an unreal case as real; which kind of thing he is ever wont to do, when he intends to set before us something in excess; as when writing to the Galatians he saith, "If we or an angel from heaven preach any other gospel unto you than that ye receive let him be accursed".

[31:151] (Gal.

[31:152] i.

[31:153] ) And yet neither was himself nor an angel about to do so; but to signify that he meant to carry the matter as far as possible, he set down even that which could never by any means happen.

[31:154] And again, when he writes to the Romans, and saith, "Neither angels, nor principalities, nor powers, shall be able to separate us from the love of God;" for neither was this about to be done by any angels: but here too he supposes a thing which was not; as indeed also in what comes next, saying, "nor any other creature," whereas there is no other creature, for he had comprehended the whole creation, having spoken of all things both above and below.

[31:155] Nevertheless here also he mentions that which was not, by way of hypothesis, so as to show his exceeding desire.

[31:156] Now the same thing he doth here also, saying, "If a man give all, and have not love, it profits him nothing".

[31:157] Either then we may say this, or that his meaning is for those who give to be also joined closely to those who retire, and not merely to give without sympathy, but in pity and condescension, bowing down and grieving with the needy.

[31:158] For therefore also hath almsgiving been enacted by God: since God might have nourished the poor as well without this, but that he might bind us together unto charity and that we might be thoroughly fervent toward each other, he commanded them to be nourished by us.

[31:159] Therefore one saith in another place also; "a good word is better than a gift;" (Ecclus.

[31:160] xviii.

[31:161] ,.

[31:162] ) and, "behold, a word is beyond a good gift".

[31:163] (Ecclus.

[31:164] xviii.

[31:165] ,.

[31:166] ) And He Himself saith, "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice".

[31:167] (S.

[31:168] Matt.

[31:169] ix.

[31:170] ; Hos.

[31:171] vi.

[31:172] ) For since it is usual, both for men to love those who are benefited by them, and for those who receive benefits to be more kindly affected towards their benefactors; he made this law, constituting it a bond of friendship.

[31:173] But the point proposed for enquiry above is, How, after Christ had said that both these belong to perfection, Paul affirms, that these without charity are imperfect? Not contradicting Him, God forbid: but harmonizing with Him, and that exactly.

[31:174] For so in the case of the rich man, He said, not merely, "sell thy goods, and give to the poor," but He added, "and come, follow Me".

[31:175] Now not even the following Him proves any man a disciple of Christ so completely as the loving one another.

[31:176] For, "by this shall all men know," saith He, "that ye are My disciples, if ye have love one to another".

[31:177] (S.

[31:178] John xiii.

[31:179] ) And also when He saith, "Whosoever loseth his life for My sake, shall find it;" (S.

[31:180] Matt.

[31:181] x.

[31:182] ,.

[31:183] ) and, "whosoever shall confess Me before men, him will I also confess before My Father which is in heaven;" He means not this, that it is not necessary to have love, but He declares the reward which is laid up for these labors.

[31:184] Since that along with martyrdom He requires also this, is what He elsewhere strongly intimates, thus saying, "Ye shall indeed drink of My cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with;" (S.

[31:185] Matt.

[31:186] xx.

[31:187] ) i-e:, ye shall be martyrs, ye shall be slain for My sake; "but to sit on My right hand, and on My left, (not as though any sit on the right hand and the left, but meaning the highest precedency and honor) "is not Mine to give," saith He, "but to those for whom it is prepared".

[31:188] Then signifying for whom it is prepared, He calls them and saith, "whosoever among you will be chief, let him be servant to you all;" (S.

[31:189] Matt.

[31:190] xx.

[31:191] ) setting forth humility and love.

[31:192] And the love which He requires is intense; wherefore He stopped not even at this, but added, "even as the Son of Man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give His life a ransom for many;" pointing out that we ought so to love as even to be slain for our beloved.

[31:193] For this above all is to love Him.

[31:194] Wherefore also He saith to Peter, "If thou lovest Me, feed My sheep".

[31:195] (S.

[31:196] John xxi.

[31:197] )   And that ye may learn how great a work of virtue it is, let us sketch it out in word, since in deeds we see it no where appearing; and let us consider, if it were every where in abundance, how great benefits would ensue: how there were no need then of laws, or tribunals or punishments, or avenging, or any other such things since if all loved and were beloved, no man would injure another.

[31:198] Yea, murders, and strifes, and wars, and divisions, and rapines, and frauds, and all evils would be removed, and vice be unknown even in name.

[31:199] Miracles, however, would not have effected this; they rather puff up such as are not on their guard, unto vain-glory and folly.

[31:200] Again: what is indeed the marvellous part of love; all the other good things have their evils yoked with them: as he that gives up his possessions is oftentimes puffed up on this account: the eloquent is affected with a wild passion for glory; the humble-minded, on this very ground, not seldom thinks highly of himself in his conscience.

[31:201] But love is free from every such mischief.

[31:202] For none could ever be lifted up against the person whom he loves.

[31:203] And do not, I pray, suppose one person only loving but all alike; and then wilt thou see its virtue.

[31:204] Or rather, if thou wilt, first suppose one single person beloved, and one loving; loving, however, as it is meet to love.

[31:205] Why, he will so live on earth as if it were heaven, every where enjoying a calm and weaving for himself innumerable crowns.

[31:206] For both from envy, and wrath, and jealousy, and pride, and vain-glory, and evil concupiscence, and every profane love, and every distemper, such a man will keep his own soul pure.

[31:207] Yea, even as no one would do himself an injury so neither would this man his neighbors.

[31:208] And being such, he shall stand with Gabriel himself, even while he walks on earth.

[31:209] Such then is he that hath love.

[31:210] But he that works miracles and hath perfect knowledge, without this, though he raises ten thousand from the dead, will not be much profited, broken off as he is from all and not enduring to mix himself up with any of his fellow-servants.

[31:211] For no other cause than this did Christ say that the sign of perfect love towards Him is the loving one's neighbors.

[31:212] For, "if thou lovest Me," saith He, "O Peter, more than these, feed My sheep".

[31:213] (S.

[31:214] John xxi.

[31:215] ) Dost thou see how hence also He again covertly intimates, in what case this is greater than martyrdom? For if any one had a beloved child in whose behalf he would even give up his life, and some one were to love the father, but pay no regard whatever to the son, he would greatly incense the father; nor would he feel the love for himself, because of the overlooking his son.

[31:216] Now if this ensue in the case of father and son, much more in the case of God and men: since surely God is more loving than any parents.

[31:217] Wherefore, having said, "The first and great commandment is, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God," he added, "and the second—(He leaves it not in silence, but sets it down also)—is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself".

[31:218] And see how with nearly the same excellency He demands also this.

[31:219] For as concerning God, He saith, "with all thy heart:" so concerning thy neighbor, "as thyself," which is tantamount to, "with all thy heart".

[31:220] Yea, and if this were duly observed, there would be neither slave nor free, neither ruler nor ruled, neither rich nor poor, neither small nor great; nor would any devil then ever have been known: I say not, Satan only, but whatever other such spirit there be, nay, rather were there a hundred or ten thousand such, they would have no power, while love existed.

[31:221] For sooner would grass endure the application of fire than the devil the flame of love.

[31:222] She is stronger than any wall, she is firmer than any adamant; or if thou canst name any material stronger than this the firmness of love transcends them all.

[31:223] Her, neither wealth nor poverty overcometh: nay, rather there would be no poverty, no unbounded wealth, if there were love, but the good parts only from each estate.

[31:224] For from the one we should reap its abundance, and from the other its freedom from care: and should neither have to undergo the anxieties of riches, nor the dread of poverty.

[31:225] And why do I mention the advantages arising from it? Yea, rather consider how great a blessing it is of itself to exercise love; what cheerfulness it produces, in how great grace it establishes the soul; a thing which above all is a choice quality of it.

[31:226] For the other parts of virtue have each their troubles yoked with them; as fasting, temperance, watching, have envy, concupiscence, and contempt.

[31:227] But love along with the gain hath great pleasure, too, and no trouble, and like an industrious bee, gathering the sweets from every flower, deposits them in the soul of him who loveth.

[31:228] Though any one be a slave, it renders slavery sweeter that liberty.

[31:229] For he who loveth rejoices not so much in commanding, as in being commanded, although to command is sweet: but love changes the nature of things and presents herself with all blessings in her hands, gentler than any mother, wealthier than any queen, and makes difficulties light and easy, causing our virtues to be facile, but vice very bitter to us.

[31:230] As thus: to expend seems grievous, yet love makes it pleasant: to receive other men's goods, pleasant, but love suffers it not to appear pleasant, but frames our minds to avoid it as an evil.

[31:231] Again, to speak evil seems to be pleasant to all; but love, while she makes this out to be bitter, causeth speaking well to be pleasant; for nothing is so sweet to us as to be praising one whom we love.

[31:232] Again, anger hath a kind of pleasure; but in this case no longer, rather all its sinews are taken away.

[31:233] Though he that is beloved should grieve him who loves him, anger no where shows itself; but tears and exhortations, and supplications; so far is love from being exasperated: and should she behold one in error, she mourns and is in pain; yet even this pain itself brings pleasure.

[31:234] For the very tears and the grief of love, are sweeter than any mirth and joy.

[31:235] For instance: they that laugh are not so refreshed as they that weep for their friends.

[31:236] And if thou doubt it, stop their tears; and they repine at it not otherwise than as persons intolerably ill-used.

[31:237] "But there is," said one, "an unbecoming pleasure in love".

[31:238] Avaunt, and hold thy peace, whoever thou art.

[31:239] For nothing is so pure from such pleasure as genuine love.

[31:240] For tell me not of this ordinary sort, the vulgar and low-minded, and a disease rather than love, but of this which Paul seeks after, which considers the profit of them that are loved; and thou shalt see that no fathers are so affectionate as persons of this stamp.

[31:241] And even as they who love money cannot endure to spend money, but would with more pleasure be in straits than see their wealth diminishing: so too, he that is kindly affected towards any one, would choose to suffer ten thousand evils than see his beloved one injured.

[31:242] "How then," saith one, "did the Egyptian woman who loved Joseph wish to injure him?" Because she loved with this diabolical love.

[31:243] Joseph however not with this, but with that which Paul requires.

[31:244] Consider then how great a love his words were tokens of, and the action which she was speaking of.

[31:245] "Insult me and make me an adulteress, and wrong my husband, and overthrow all my house, and cast thyself out from thy confidence towards God:" which were expressions of one who so far from loving him did not even love herself.

[31:246] But because he truly loved, he sought to avert her from all these.

[31:247] And to convince you that it was in anxiety for her, learn the nature of it from his advice.

[31:248] For he not only thrust her away, but also introduced an exhortation capable of quenching every flame: namely "if on my account, my master," saith he, "knoweth not any thing which is in his house".

[31:249] He at once reminds her of her husband that he might put her to shame.

[31:250] And he said not, "thy husband," but "my master," which was more apt to restrain her and induce her to consider who she was, and of whom she was enamored,—a mistress, of a slave.

[31:251] "For if he be lord, then art thou mistress.

[31:252] Be ashamed then of familiarity with a servant, and consider whose wife thou art, and with whom thou wouldst be connected, and towards whom thou art becoming thankless and inconsiderate, and that I repay him greater good-will".

[31:253] And see how he extols his benefits.

[31:254] For since that barbarous and abandoned woman could entertain no lofty sentiment, he shames her from human considerations, saying, "He knoweth nothing through me," i-e:, "he is a great benefactor to me, and I cannot strike my patron in a vital part.

[31:255] He hath made me a second lord of his house, and no one hath been kept back from me, but thee".

[31:256] Here he endeavors to raise her mind, that so at any rate he might persuade her to be ashamed, and might signify the greatness of her honor.

[31:257] Nor did he stop even here, but likewise added a name sufficient to restrain her, saying, "Because thou art his wife; and how shall I do this wickedness? But what sayest thou? That thy husband is not present, nor knoweth that he is wronged? But God will behold it".

[31:258] She however profited nothing by his advice, but still sought to attract him.

[31:259] For desiring to satiate her own frenzy, not through love of Joseph, she did these things; and this is evident from what she did afterwards.

[31:260] As that she institutes a trial, and brings in accusation, and bears false witness, and exposes to a wild beast him that had done no wrong, and casts him into a prison; or rather for her part, she even slew him, in such a manner did she arm the judge against him.

[31:261] What then? Was then Joseph too such as she was? Nay, altogether the contrary, for he neither contradicted nor accused the woman.

[31:262] "Yes," it may be said: "for he would have been disbelieved".

[31:263] And yet he was greatly beloved; and this is evident not only from the beginning but also from the end.

[31:264] For had not his barbarian master loved him greatly, he would even have slain him in his silence, making no defence: being as he was an Egyptian and a ruler, and wronged in his marriage-bed as he supposed, and by a servant, and a servant to whom he had been so great a benefactor.

[31:265] But all these things gave way to his regard for him, and the grace which God poured down upon him.

[31:266] And together with this grace and love, he had also other no small proofs, had he been minded to justify himself; the garments themselves.

[31:267] For if it were she to whom violence was done, her own vest should have been torn, her face lacerated, instead of her retaining his garments.

[31:268] But "he heard," saith she, "that I lifted up my voice, and left his garments, and went out".

[31:269] And wherefore then didst thou take them from him? since unto one suffering violence, the one thing desirable is to be rid of the intruder.

[31:270] But not from hence alone, but also from the subsequent events, shall I be able to point out his good-will and his love.

[31:271] Yea even when he fell into a necessity of mentioning the cause of his imprisonment, and his remaining there, he did not even then declare the whole course of the story.

[31:272] But what saith he? "I too have done nothing: but indeed I was stolen out of the land of the Hebrews;" and he no where mentioned the adulteress nor doth he plume himself on the matter, which would have been any one's feeling, if not for vain-glory, yet so as not to appear to have been cast into that cell for an evil cause.

[31:273] For if men in the act of doing wrong by no means abstain even so from blaming the same things, although to do so brings reproach; of what admiration is not he worthy, because, pure as he was he did not mention the woman's passion nor make a show of her sin; nor when he ascended the throne and became ruler of all Egypt, remember the wrong done by the woman nor exact any punishment?  Seest thou how he cared for her? but her's was not love, but madness.

[31:274] For it was not Joseph that she loved, but she sought to fulfil her own lust.

[31:275] And the very words too, if one would examine them accurately, were accompanied with wrath and great blood-thirstiness.

[31:276] For what saith she? "Thou hast brought in a Hebrew servant to mock us:" upbraiding her husband for the kindness; and she exhibited the garments, having become herself more savage than any wild beast: but not so he.

[31:277] And why speak I of his good-will to her, when he was such, we know, towards his brethren who would slay him; and never said one harsh thing of them, either within doors or without?   Therefore Paul saith, that the love which we are speaking of is the mother of all good things, and prefers it to miracles and all other gifts.

[31:278] For as where there are vests and sandals of gold, we require also some other garments whereby to distinguish the king: but if we see the purple and the diadem, we require not to see any other sign of his royalty: just so here likewise, when the diadem of love is upon our head, it is enough to point out the genuine disciple of Christ, not to ourselves only, but also to the unbelievers.

[31:279] For, "by this," saith He, "shall all men know that ye are My disciples, if ye have love one to another".

[31:280] (S.

[31:281] John xiii.

[31:282] ) So that this sign is greater surely than all signs, in that the disciple is recognised by it.

[31:283] For though any should work ten thousand signs, but be at strife one with another, they will be a scorn to the unbelievers.

[31:284] Just as if they do no sign, but love one another exactly, they will continue both reverenced and inviolable by all men.

[31:285] Since Paul himself we admire on this account, not for the dead whom he raised, nor for the lepers whom he cleansed, but because he said, "who is weak, and I am not weak? who is made to stumble, and I burn not?" ( Cor.

[31:286] xi.

[31:287] ) For shouldest thou have ten thousand miracles to compare with this, thou wilt have nothing equal to it to say.

[31:288] Since Paul also himself said, that a great reward was laid up for him, not because he wrought miracles, but because "to the weak he became as weak.

[31:289] For what is my reward?" saith he.

[31:290] "That, when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel without charge".

[31:291] ( Cor.

[31:292] ix.

[31:293] ) And when he puts himself before the Apostles, he saith not, "I have wrought miracles more abundant than they," but, "I have labored more abundantly than they".

[31:294] ( Cor.

[31:295] xv.

[31:296] ) And even by famine was he willing to perish for the salvation of the disciples.

[31:297] "For it were better for me to die," saith he, "than that any man should make my glorying void:" ( Cor.

[31:298] ix.

[31:299] ) not because he was glorying, but that he might not seem to reproach them.

[31:300] For he no where is wont to glory in his own achievements, when the season doth not call to it; but even if he be compelled so to do he calleth himself "a fool".

[31:301] But if he ever glory it is "in infirmities," in wrongs, in greatly sympathizing with those who are injured: even as here also he saith, "who is weak, and I am not weak?" These words are greater even than perils.

[31:302] Wherefore also he sets them last, amplifying his discourse.

[31:303] Of what then must we be worthy compared with him, who neither contemn wealth for our own sake, nor give up the superfluities of our goods? But not so Paul; rather both soul and body did he use to give up, that they who stoned and beat him with rods, might obtain the kingdom.

[31:304] "For thus," saith he, "hath Christ taught me to love;" who left behind Him the new commandment concerning love, which also Himself fulfilled in deed.

[31:305] For being Lord of all, and of that Blessed Nature; from men, whom He created out of nothing and on whom He had bestowed innumerable benefits, from these, insulting and spitting on Him, He turned not away, but even became man for their sakes, and conversed with harlots and publicans, and healed the demoniacs, and promised heaven.

[31:306] And after all these things they apprehended and beat him with rods, bound, scourged, mocked, and at last crucified Him.

[31:307] And not even so did He turn away, but even when He was on high upon the cross, He saith, "Father, forgive them their sin".

[31:308] But the thief who before this reviled Him, He translated into very paradise; and made the persecutor Paul, an Apostle; and gave up His own disciples, who were His intimates and wholly devoted to Him, unto death for the Jews' sake who crucified Him.

[31:309] Recollecting therefore in our minds all these things, both those of God and of men, let us emulate these high deeds, and possess ourselves of the love which is above all gifts, that we may obtain both the present and the future blessings: the which may we all obtain, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

[32:1] Homily XXXIII.

[32:2] Cor.

[32:3] xiii.

[32:4] Love suffereth long, and is kind; love envieth not; love vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up.

[32:5] Thus, whereas he had showed, that both faith and knowledge and prophecy and tongues and gifts and healing and a perfect life and martyrdom, if love be absent, are no great advantage; of necessity he next makes an outline of its matchless beauty, adorning its image with the parts of virtue as with a sort of colors, and putting together all its members with exactness.

[32:6] But do not thou hastily pass by, beloved, the things spoken, but examine each one of them with much care, that thou mayest know both the treasure which is in the thing and the art of the painter.

[32:7] Consider, for example, from what point he at once began, and what he set first, as the cause of all its excellence.

[32:8] And what is this? Long-suffering.

[32:9] This is the root of all self-denial.

[32:10] Wherefore also a certain wise man said, "A man that is long-suffering is of great understanding; but he that is hasty of spirit is mightily foolish".

[32:11] And comparing it too with a strong city, he said that it is more secure than that.

[32:12] For it is both an invincible weapon and a sort of impregnable tower, easily beating off all annoyances.

[32:13] And as a spark falling into the deep doth it no injury, but is itself easily quenched: so upon a long-suffering soul whatever unexpected thing falls, this indeed speedily vanishes, but the soul it disturbs not: for of a truth there is nothing so impenetrable as long-suffering.

[32:14] You may talk of armies, money, horses, walls, arms, or any thing else whatsoever; you will name nothing like long-suffering.

[32:15] For he that is encompassed with those, oftentimes, being overcome by anger, is upset like a worthless child, and fills all with confusion and tempest: but this man, settled as it were in a harbor, enjoys a profound calm.

[32:16] Though thou surround him with loss, thou hast not moved the rock; though thou bring insult upon him, thou hast not shaken the tower: and though thou bruise him with stripes, thou hast not wounded the adamant.

[32:17] Yea, and therefore is he called long-suffering, because he hath a kind of long and great soul.

[32:18] For that which is long is also called great.

[32:19] But this excellence is born of love, both to them who possess and to them who enjoy it contributing no small advantage.

[32:20] For tell me not of those abandoned wretches, who, doing evil and suffering none, become worse: since here, not from his long-suffering, but from those who abuse it, this result arises.

[32:21] Tell me not therefore of these, but of those gentler persons, who gain great benefit therefrom.

[32:22] For when, having done ill, they suffer none, admiring the meekness of the sufferer, they reap thereby a very great lesson of self command.

[32:23] But Paul doth not stop here, but adds also the other high achievements of love, saying, "is kind".

[32:24] For since there are some who practise their long-suffering with a view not to their own self-denial, but to the punishment of those who have provoked them, to make them burst with wrath; he saith that neither hath charity this defect.

[32:25] Wherefore also he added, "is kind".

[32:26] For not at all with a view to light up the fire, in those who are inflamed by anger, do they deal more gently with them, but in order to appease and extinguish it: and not only by enduring nobly, but also by soothing and comforting, do they cure the sore and heal the wound of passion.

[32:27] "Envieth not".

[32:28] For it is possible for one to be both long-suffering and envious, and thereby that excellency is spoiled.

[32:29] But love avoids this also.

[32:30] "Vaunteth not itself;" i-e:, is not rash.

[32:31] For it renders him who loves both considerate, and grave, and steadfast.

[32:32] In truth, one mark of those who love unlawfully is a defect in this point.

[32:33] Whereas he to whom this love is known, is of all men the most entirely freed from these evils.

[32:34] For when there is no anger within, both rashness and insolence are clean taken away.

[32:35] Love, like some excellent husbandman, taking her seat inwardly in the soul and not suffering any of these thorns to spring up.

[32:36] "Is not puffed up".

[32:37] For so we see many who think highly of themselves on the score of these very excellencies; for example, on not being envious, nor grudging, nor mean-spirited, nor rash: these evils being incidental not to wealth and poverty only, but even to things naturally good.

[32:38] But love perfectly purges out all.

[32:39] And consider: he that is long-suffering is not of course also kind.

[32:40] But if he be not kind, the thing becomes a vice, and he is in danger of falling into malice.

[32:41] Therefore she supplies a medicine, I mean kindness, and preserves the virtue pure.

[32:42] Again, the kind person often becomes over-complaisant; but this also she corrects.

[32:43] For "love," saith he, "vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up:" the kind and long-suffering is often ostentatious; but she takes away this vice also.

[32:44] And see how he adorns her not only from what she hath, but also from what she hath not.

[32:45] For he saith that she both brings in virtue, and extirpates vice, nay rather she suffers it not to spring up at all.

[32:46] Thus he said not, "She envieth, indeed, but overcometh envy;" nor, "is arrogant, but chastiseth that passion;" but, "envieth not, vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up;" which truly is most to be admired, that even without toil she accomplishes her good things, and without war and battle-array her trophy is set up: she not permitting him that possesseth her to toil and so to attain the crown, but without labor conveying to him her prize.

[32:47] For where there is not passion to contend against sober reason, what labor can there be?   "Doth not behave itself unseemly".

[32:48] "Nay, why," saith he, "do I say, she 'is not puffed up,' when she is so far from that feeling, that in suffering the most shameful things for him whom she loves, she doth not even count the thing an unseemliness?" Again, he did not say, "she suffereth unseemliness but beareth the shame nobly," but, "she doth not even entertain any sense at all of the shame".

[32:49] For if the lovers of money endure all manner of reproaches for the sake of that sordid traffic of theirs, and far from hiding their faces, do even exult in it: much more he that hath this praiseworthy love will refuse nothing whatsoever for the safety's sake of those whom he loves: nay, nor will any thing that he can suffer shame him.

[32:50] And that we may not fetch our example from any thing base, let us examine this same statement in its application to Christ, and then we shall see the force of what hath been said.

[32:51] For our Lord Jesus Christ was both spit upon and beaten with rods by pitiful slaves; and not only did He not count it an unseemliness, but He even exulted and called the thing glory; and bringing in a robber and murderer with Himself before the rest into paradise, and discoursing with a harlot, and this when the standers-by all accused Him, He counted not the thing to be disgraceful, but both allowed her to kiss His feet, and to bedew His body with her tears, and to wipe them away with her hair, and this amid a company of spectators who were foes and enemies; "for love doeth nothing unseemly".

[32:52] Therefore also fathers, though they be the first of philosophers and orators, are not ashamed to lisp with their children; and none of those who see them find fault with them, but the thing is esteemed so good and right as to be even worthy of prayer.

[32:53] And again, should they become vicious, the parents keep on correcting, caring for them, abridging the reproaches they incur, and are not ashamed.

[32:54] For love "doth nothing unseemly," but as it were with certain golden wings covereth up all the offences of the beloved.

[32:55] Thus also Jonathan loved David; and hearing his father say, ( Sam.

[32:56] xx.

[32:57] ) "Thou son of damsels that have run away from their homes, thou womanly bred," he was not ashamed, though the words be full of great reproach.

[32:58] For what he means is this: "Thou son of mean harlots who are mad after men, who run after the passers-by, thou unnerved and effeminate wretch, who hast nothing of a man, but livest to the shame of thyself and the mother who bare thee".

[32:59] What then? Did he grieve at these things, and hide his face, and turn away from his beloved? Nay, quite the contrary; he displayed his fondness as an ornament.

[32:60] And yet the one was at that time a king, and a king's son, even Jonathan; the other a fugitive and a wanderer, I mean, David.

[32:61] But not even thus was he ashamed of his friendship.

[32:62] "For love doth not behave itself unseemly.

[32:63] Yea, this is its wonderful quality that not only it suffers not the injured to grieve and feel galled, but even disposes him to rejoice.

[32:64] Accordingly, he too, of whom we are speaking, after all these things, just as though he had a crown put on him, went away and fell on David's neck.

[32:65] For love knows not what sort of thing shame may be.

[32:66] Therefore it glories in those things for which another hides his face.

[32:67] Since the shame is, not to know how to love; not, when thou lovest, to incur danger and endure all for the beloved.

[32:68] But when I say, "all," do not suppose I mean things injurious also; for example, assisting a youth in a love affair, or whatsoever hurtful thing any one may beseech another to do for him.

[32:69] For such a person doth not love, and this I showed you lately from the Egyptian woman: since in truth he only is the lover who seeks what is profitable to the beloved: so that if any pursue not this, even what is right and good, though he make ten thousand professions of love, he is more hostile than any enemies.

[32:70] So also Rebecca aforetime, because she exceedingly clung to her son, both perpetrated a theft, and was not ashamed of detection, neither was she afraid, though the risk was no common one; but even when her son raised scruples to her, "upon me be thy curse, my son," she said.

[32:71] Dost thou see even in a woman the soul of the Apostle how, even as Paul chose, (if one may compare a small thing with a great,) to be anathema for the Jews' sake, (Rom.

[32:72] ix.

[32:73] ) so also she, that her son might be blessed, chose to be no less than accursed.

[32:74] And the good things she gave up to him, for she was not, it seems, to be blessed with him, but the evils she was prepared to endure herself alone: nevertheless, she rejoiced, and hasted, and this where so great a danger lay before her, and she was grieved at the delay of the business: for she feared lest Esau might anticipate them and render her wisdom vain.

[32:75] Wherefore also she cuts short the conversation and urges on the young man, and just permitting him to answer what had been said, states a reason sufficient to persuade him.

[32:76] For she said not, "thou sayest these things without reason, and in vain thou fearest, thy father having grown old and being deprived of clearness of sight:" but what? "upon me be thy curse, my son.

[32:77] Only do thou not mar the plot, nor lose the object of our chase, nor give up the treasure".

[32:78] And this very Jacob, served he not for wages with his kinsmen twice seven years? Was he not together with the bondage subject to mockery in respect of that trick? What then? Did he feel the mockery? Did he count it behaving himself unseemly, that being a freeman, and free born, and well brought up, he endured slaves' treatment among his own kinsmen: a thing which is wont to be most vexing, when one receives opprobrious treatment from one's friends? In no wise.

[32:79] And the cause was his love, which made the time, though long, appear short.

[32:80] "For they were," saith he, (Gen.

[32:81] xxix.

[32:82] ) "in his sight as a few days".

[32:83] So far was he from being galled and blushing for this his bondage.

[32:84] Justly then said the blessed Paul, "Love doth not behave itself unseemly".

[32:85] "Seeketh not its own, is not provoked".

[32:86] Thus having said, "doth not behave itself unseemly," he showeth also the temper of mind, on account of which she doth not behave herself unseemly.

[32:87] And what is that temper? That she "seeketh not her own".

[32:88] For the beloved she esteems to be all, and then only "behaveth herself unseemly," when she cannot free him from such unseemliness; so that if it be possible by her own unseemliness to benefit her beloved, she doth not so much as count the thing unseemliness; for the other party thereafter is yourself, when you love: since this is friendship, that the lover and the beloved should no longer be two persons divided, but in a manner one single person; a thing which no how takes place except from love.

[32:89] Seek not therefore thine own, that thou mayest find thine own.

[32:90] For he that seeks his own, finds not his own.

[32:91] Wherefore also Paul said, "Let no man seek his own, but each his neighbor's good".

[32:92] ( Cor.

[32:93] x.

[32:94] ) For your own profit lies in the profit of your neighbor, and his in yours.

[32:95] As therefore one that had his own gold buried in the house of his neighbor, should he refuse to go and there seek and dig it up, will never seek it; so likewise here, he that will not seek his own profit in the advantage of his neighbor, will not attain unto the crowns due to this: God Himself having therefore so disposed of it, in order that we should be mutually bound together: and even as one awakening a slumbering child to follow his brother, when he is of himself unwilling, places in the brother's hand that which he desires and longs for, that through desire of obtaining it he may pursue after him that holds it, and accordingly so it takes place: thus also here, each man's own profit hath he given to his neighbor, that hence we may run after one another, and not be torn asunder.

[32:96] And if thou wilt, see this also in our case who address you.

[32:97] For my profit depends on thee, and thy advantage on me.

[32:98] Thus, on the one hand it profits thee to be taught the things that please God, but with this have I been entrusted, that thou mightest receive it from me, and therefore mightest be compelled to run unto me; and on the other hand it profits me that thou shouldest be made better: for the reward which I shall receive for this will be great; but this again lieth in thee; and therefore am I compelled to follow after thee that thou mayest be better, and that I may receive my profit from thee.

[32:99] Wherefore also Paul saith, "For what is my hope? are not even ye?" And again, "My hope, and my joy, and the crown of my rejoicing".

[32:100] ( Thess.

[32:101] ii.

[32:102] ) So that the joy of Paul was the disciples, and his joy they had.

[32:103] Therefore he even wept when he saw them perishing.

[32:104] Again their profit depended on Paul: wherefore he said, "For the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.

[32:105] (Acts xxviii.

[32:106] ) And again, "These things I endure for the elect's sakes that they may obtain eternal life.

[32:107] ( Tim.

[32:108] ii.

[32:109] ) And this one may see in worldly things.

[32:110] "For the wife," saith he, "hath not power over her own body, nor yet the husband; but the wife over the husband's, and the husband over the wife's".

[32:111] ( Cor.

[32:112] vii.

[32:113] ) So likewise we, when we wish to bind any together, do this.

[32:114] We leave neither of them in his own power, but extending a chain between them, we cause the one to be holden of the other, and the other of the one.

[32:115] Wilt thou also see this in the case of governors? He that judges sits not in judgment for himself, but seeking the profit of his neighbor.

[32:116] The governed on the other hand, seek the profit of the governor by their attendance, by their ministry, by all the other things.

[32:117] Soldiers take up their arms for us, for on our account they peril themselves.

[32:118] We for them are in straits; for from us are their supplies.

[32:119] But if thou sayest, "each one doth this seeking his own," this also say I, but I add, that by the good of another one's own is won.

[32:120] Thus both the soldier, unless he fight for them that support him, hath none that ministers to him for this end: and this same on the other hand, unless he nourish the soldier, hath none to arm himself in his behalf.

[32:121] Seest thou love, how it is everywhere extended and manages all things? But be not weary, until thou have thoroughly acquainted thyself with this golden chain.

[32:122] For having said, "seeketh not her own," he mentions again the good things produced by this.

[32:123] And what are these?  "Is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil".

[32:124] See love again not only subduing vice, but not even suffering it to arise at all.

[32:125] For he said not, "though provoked, she overcomes," but, "is not provoked".

[32:126] And he said not, "worketh no evil," but, "not even thinketh;" i-e:, so far from contriving any evil, she doth not even suspect it of the beloved.

[32:127] How then could she work any, or how be provoked? who doth not even endure to admit an evil surmise; whence is the fountain of wrath.

[32:128] Ver.

[32:129] "Rejoiceth not in unrighteousness:" i-e:, doth not feel pleasure over those that suffer ill: and not this only, but also, what is much greater, "rejoiceth with the truth".

[32:130] "She feels pleasure," saith he, "with them that are well spoken of," as Paul saith, "Rejoice with them that rejoice, and weep with them that weep".

[32:131] (Rom.

[32:132] xii.

[32:133] )  Hence, she "envieth not," hence she "is not puffed up:" since in fact she accounts the good things of others her own.

[32:134] Seest thou how by degrees love makes her nursling an angel? For when he is void of anger, and pure from envy, and free from every tyrannical passion, consider that even from the nature of man he is delivered from henceforth, and hath arrived at the very serenity of angels.

[32:135] Nevertheless, he is not content with these, but hath something even more than these to say: according to his plan of stating the stronger points later.

[32:136] Wherefore he saith, "beareth all things".

[32:137] From her long-suffering, from her goodness; whether they be burdensome, or grievous, or insults, or stripes, or death, or whatsoever else.

[32:138] And this again one may perceive from the case of blessed David.

[32:139] For what could be more intolerable than to see a son rising up against him, and aiming at the usurpation, and thirsting for a father's blood? Yet this did that blessed one endure, nor even so could he bear to throw out one bitter expression against the parricide; but even when he left all the rest to his captains, gave a strong injunction respecting his safety.

[32:140] For strong was the foundation of his love.

[32:141] Wherefore also it "beareth all things".

[32:142] Now its power the Apostle here intimates, but its goodness, by what follows.

[32:143] For, "it hopeth all things," saith he, "believeth all things, endureth all things".

[32:144] What is, "hopeth all things?" It doth not despair," saith he, "of the beloved, but even though he be worthless, it continues to correct, to provide, to care for him".

[32:145] "Believeth all things".

[32:146] "For it doth not merely hope," saith he, "but also believeth from its great affection".

[32:147] And even if these good things should not turn out according to its hope, but the other person should prove yet more intolerable, it bears even these.

[32:148] For, saith he, it "endureth all things".

[32:149] Ver.

[32:150] "Love never faileth".

[32:151] Seest thou when he put the crown on the arch, and what of all things is peculiar to this gift? For what is, "faileth not?" it is not severed, is not dissolved by endurance.

[32:152] For it puts up with everything: since happen what will, he that loves never can hate.

[32:153] This then is the greatest of its excellencies.

[32:154] Such a person was Paul.

[32:155] Wherefore also he said, "If by any means I may provoke to emulation them which are my flesh;" (Rom.

[32:156] xi.

[32:157] ) and he continued hoping.

[32:158] And to Timothy he gave a charge, saying, "And the Lord's servant must not strive, but be gentle towards all.

[32:159] …in meekness correcting those that oppose themselves, if God peradventure may give them the knowledge of the truth".

[32:160] ( Tim.

[32:161] ii.

[32:162] ,.

[32:163] )  "What then," saith one, "if they be enemies and heathens, must one hate them?" One must hate, not them but their doctrine: not the man, but the wicked conduct, the corrupt mind.

[32:164] For the man is God's work, but the deceit is the devil's work.

[32:165] Do thou not therefore confound the things of God and the things of the devil.

[32:166] Since the Jews were both blasphemers, and persecutors, and injurious, and spake ten thousand evil things of Christ.

[32:167] Did Paul then hate them, he who of all men most loved Christ? In no wise, but he both loved them, and did everything for their sakes: and at one time he saith, "My heart's desire and my supplication to God is for them that they may be saved:" (Rom.

[32:168] x.

[32:169] ; ix.

[32:170] ) and at another, "I could wish that myself were anathema from Christ for their sakes".

[32:171] Thus also Ezekiel seeing them slain saith, "Alas, O Lord, dost Thou blot out the remnant of Israel?" (Ezek.

[32:172] ix.

[32:173] ) And Moses, "If Thou wilt forgive their sin, forgive".

[32:174] (Exod.

[32:175] xxxii.

[32:176] )  Why then saith David, "Do not I hate them, O Lord, that hate Thee, and against Thine enemies did I not pine away? I hate them with perfect hatred".

[32:177] (Ps.

[32:178] cxxxix.

[32:179] ,.

[32:180] )  Now, in the first place, not all things spoken in the Psalms by David, are spoken in the person of David.

[32:181] For it is he himself who saith, "I have dwelt in the tents of Kedar;" (Ps.

[32:182] cxx.

[32:183] ) and, "By the waters of Babylon, there we sat down and wept:" (cxxxvii.

[32:184] ) yet he neither saw Babylon, nor the tents of Kedar.

[32:185] But besides this, we require now a completer self-command.

[32:186] Wherefore also when the disciples besought that fire might come down, even as in the case of Elias, "Ye know not," saith Christ, "what manner of spirit ye are of.

[32:187] (Luke ix.

[32:188] ) For at that time not the ungodliness only, but also the ungodly themselves, they were commanded to hate, in order that their friendship might not prove an occasion of transgression unto them.

[32:189] Therefore he severed their connections, both by blood and marriage, and on every side he fenced them off.

[32:190] But now because he hath brought us to a more entire self-command and set us on high above that mischief, he bids us rather admit and soothe them.

[32:191] For we get no harm from them, but they get good by us.

[32:192] What then doth he say? we must not hate, but pity.

[32:193] Since if thou shalt hate, how wilt thou easily convert him that is in error? how wilt thou pray for the unbeliever? for that one ought to pray, hear what Paul saith: "I exhort therefore, first of all, that supplications, prayer, intercessions, thanksgivings be made for all men".

[32:194] ( Tim.

[32:195] ii.

[32:196] ) But that all were not then believers, is, I suppose, evident unto every one.

[32:197] And again, "for kings and all that are in high place".

[32:198] But that these were ungodly and transgressors, this also is equally manifest.

[32:199] Further, mentioning also the reason for the prayer, he adds, "for this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour; who willeth that all men should be saved, and come to the knowledge of the truth".

[32:200] Therefore, if he find a Gentile wife consorting with a believer, he dissolves not the marriage.

[32:201] Yet what is more closely joined than a man to his wife? "For they two shall be one flesh," (Gen.

[32:202] ii.

[32:203] ) and great in that instance is the charm, and ardent the desire.

[32:204] But if we are to hate ungodly and lawless men, we shall go on to hate also sinners; and thus in regular process thou wilt be broken off from the most even of thy brethren, or rather from all: for there is not one, no, not one, without sin.

[32:205] For if it be our duty to hate the enemies of God, one must not hate the ungodly only, but also sinners: and thus we shall be worse than wild beasts, shunning all, and puffed up with pride; even as that Pharisee.

[32:206] But not thus did Paul command us, but how? "Admonish the disorderly, encourage the faint-hearted, support the weak, be long suffering toward all".

[32:207] ( Thess.

[32:208] v.

[32:209] )   What then doth he mean when he saith, "If any obeyeth not our word by this epistle, note that man, that ye have no company with him?" ( Thess.

[32:210] iii.

[32:211] ) In the first place, he saith this of brethren, however not even so without limitation, but this too with gentleness.

[32:212] For do not thou cut off what follows, but subjoin also the next clause: how, having said, "keep no company," he added, "yet count him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother".

[32:213] Seest thou how he bade us hate the deed that is evil, and not the man? For indeed it is the work of the devil to tear us asunder from one another, and he hath ever used great diligence to take away love that he may cut off the way of correction, and may retain him in error and thee in enmity, and thus block up the way of his salvation.

[32:214] For when both the physician hates the sick man and flies from him, and the sick man turns away from the physician, when will the distempered person be restored, seeing that neither the one will call in the other's aid, nor will the other go to him?  But wherefore, tell me, dost thou at all turn away from him and avoid him? Because he is ungodly? Truly for this cause oughtest thou to welcome and attend him, that thou mayest raise him up in his sickness.

[32:215] But if he be incurably sick, still thou hast been bidden to do thy part.

[32:216] Since Judas also was incurably diseased, yet God left not off attending upon him.

[32:217] Wherefore, neither do thou grow weary.

[32:218] For even if after much labor thou fail to deliver him from his ungodliness, yet shalt thou receive the deliverer's reward, and wilt cause him to wonder at thy gentleness, and so all this praise will pass on to God.

[32:219] For though thou shouldest work wonders, and raise the dead, and whatsoever work thou doest, the Heathen will never wonder at thee so much, as when they see thee displaying a meek, gentle, mild disposition.

[32:220] And this is no small achievement: since many will even be entirely delivered from their evil way; there being nothing that hath such power to allure men as love.

[32:221] For in respect of the former they will rather be jealous of thee, I mean the signs and wonders; but for this they will both admire and love thee: and if they love, they will also lay hold of the truth in due course.

[32:222] If however he become not all at once a believer, wonder not nor hurry on, neither do thou require all things at once, but suffer him for the present to praise, and love, and unto this in due course he will come.

[32:223] And that thou mayest clearly know how great a thing this is, hear how even Paul, going before an unbelieving judge, made his defence.

[32:224] "I think myself happy," saith he, "That I am to make my defence before thee".

[32:225] (Acts xxvi.

[32:226] ) And these things he said, not to flatter him, far from it; but wishing to gain him by his gentleness.

[32:227] And he did in part gain him, and he that was till then considered to be condemned took captive his judge, and the victory is confessed by the person himself who was made captive, with a loud voice in the presence of all, saying, "With but little persuasion thou wouldst fain make me a Christian".

[32:228] (Acts xxvi.

[32:229] ,.

[32:230] ) What then saith Paul? He spread his net the wider, and saith, "I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, might become such as I am, except these bonds".

[32:231] What sayest thou, O Paul? "except these bonds?" And what confidence remains for thee, if thou art ashamed of these things, and fliest from them, and this before so great a multitude? Dost thou not every where in thy Epistles boast of this matter, and call thyself a prisoner? Dost thou not every where carry about this chain in our sight as a diadem? What then hath happened now that thou deprecatest these bonds? "I myself deprecate them not," saith he, "nor am I ashamed of them, but I condescend to their weakness.

[32:232] For they are not yet able to receive my glorying; and I have learned from my Lord not to put 'a piece of undressed cloth upon an old garment:' (S.

[32:233] Matt.

[32:234] ix.

[32:235] ) therefore did I thus speak.

[32:236] For, in fact, unto this time they have heard ill reports of our doctrine, and abhor the cross.

[32:237] If therefore I should add also bonds, their hatred becometh greater; I removed these, therefore, that the other might be made acceptable.

[32:238] So it is, that to them it seems disgraceful to be bound, because they have not as yet tasted of the Glory which is with us.

[32:239] One must therefore condescend: and when they shall have learned of the true life, then will they know the beauty also of this iron, and the lustre which comes of these bonds".

[32:240] Furthermore, discoursing with others, he even calls the thing a free gift, saying, "It hath been granted in the behalf of Christ, not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer in His behalf".

[32:241] (Philip.

[32:242] i.

[32:243] ) But for the time then present, it was a great thing for the hearers not to be ashamed of the cross: for which cause he goes on gradually.

[32:244] Thus, neither doth any one introducing a person to a palace, before that he beholds the vestibule, compel him, yet standing without, to survey what is within: since in that way it will not even seem admirable, unless one enter in and so acquaint one's self with all.

[32:245] So then let us also deal with the heathen sort: with condecension, with love.

[32:246] For love is a great teacher, and able both to withdraw men from error, and to reform the character, and to lead them by the hand unto self-denial, and out of stones to make men.

[32:247] And if thou wouldest learn her power, bring me a man timid and fearful of every sound, and trembling at shadows; or passionate, and harsh, and a wild beast rather than a man; or wanton and licentious; or wholly given to wickedness; and deliver him into the hands of love, and introduce him into this school; and thou wilt speedily see that cowardly and timid creature made brave and magnanimous, and venturing upon all things cheerfully.

[32:248] And what is wonderful, not from any change in nature do these things result, but in the coward soul itself love manifests her peculiar power; and it is much the same as if one should cause a leaden sword, not turned into steel but continuing in the nature of lead, to do the work of steel.

[32:249] As thus: Jacob was a "plain man, (Gen.

[32:250] xxv.

[32:251] ) dwelling in a house, and unpracticed in toils and dangers, living a kind of remiss and easy life, and like a virgin in her chamber, so also he was compelled for the most part to sit within doors and keep the house; withdrawn from the forum and all tumults of the forum, and from all such matters, and even continuing in ease and quietness.

[32:252] What then? After that the torch of love had set him on fire, see how it made this plain and home-keeping man strong to endure and fond of toil.

[32:253] And of this hear not what I say, but what the patriarch himself saith: how finding fault with his kinsman, his words are, "These twenty years am I with thee".

[32:254] (Gen.

[32:255] xxxi.
